construed to grant or deny any employees organized under the public employment labor relations
act of 1971, as amended, any benefits, protections, or advantages negotiated and expressed
within their labor agreement(s).
(B) The city's employment policy manual shall contain the current personnel policies and procedures
and terms and conditions of employment that guide employment decisions in the city. The policies
and regulations contained in the employment policy manual will be amended or replaced by the
city manager as needed and in compliance with the governance executive limitation policies on
staff treatment and compensation and benefits. Any proposed changes which have a financial
impact to the city will require city council approval. (Ord. 1095, 10-1-2007)
1-6-5: EXCEPTED PERSONS:
The sections of this chapter, unless specifically noted otherwise, shall apply to all municipal
employees, except:
(A) Elected officials;
(B) Committee and commission members;
(C) Consultants rendering professional services; (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
(D) Employees specifically covered by a collectively bargained labor agreement, to the extent that the
labor agreement controls; (Ord. 1095, 10-1-2007)
(E) City manager and any other person employed through a direct employment contract with the city
council. Nothing herein, however, shall be construed to bar the application of this chapter, or
sections thereof, to these individuals by separate agreement or city council resolution;
(F) Part time and temporary employees; and
(G) Individuals within volunteer programs administered or assisted by the city. (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
1-6-6: FUNDAMENTAL PERSONNEL POLICIES:
The policies of this section are basic commitments of the city. These policies shall guide the
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 65/771
interpretation and application of all other sections of this chapter and shall be applied, whenever
feasible, to any other personnel matter involving the city: (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
(A) Management Rights: Except as limited by state and federal law, the city manager or the city
manager's designee, has the authority, powers, and rights necessary for the efficient and effective
management of all personnel matters, including, but not limited to, the following powers: (Ord. 279,
7-15-1985)
1. To prescribe and administer rules and regulations essential to the accomplishment of the
services desired by the city council.
2. To manage and otherwise supervise all employees.
3. To hire, promote, transfer, assign, and retain employees and to suspend, demote, dismiss, or
take other disciplinary action against employees as circumstances warrant.
4. To relieve employees of duties because of lack of work, lack of funds, or for other legitimate
reasons.
5. To maintain the efficiency and economy of the city operations entrusted to the administration.
6. To determine the methods, means, and personnel by which such operations are to be
conducted.
7. To take whatever action may be necessary to carry out the objectives of the city council in
emergency situations.
8. To exercise discretion in the operation of the city, the budget, organization, assignment of
personnel, and the technology of work performance.
(B) Merit, Fitness, Equity And Efficiency: Employment shall be based upon merit and fitness. Just and
equitable terms and conditions of employment shall be established and maintained to promote
efficiency and economy in the operation of the city government. Employee tenure shall be subject
to good behavior, satisfactory performance, work necessity, and availability of funds.
(C) Equal Employment Opportunity: All matters of personnel administration shall be conducted with
full regard for the duties and obligations placed upon the city by the Minnesota human rights act,
Minnesota statutes, chapter 363, and applicable federal statutes, rules and orders. Each employee
and all levels of management shall support and participate in the implementation of the city's equal
employment opportunity and human rights policies.
(D) Veteran Preference: Veterans shall be hired and employed in accordance with the requirements
set forth by state and federal laws. Reasonable proof of military service may be required as a
condition of the application of this preference.
(E) Residency Requirements And Preferences: There shall be no general residency requirement for
employees of the city. Forthe purpose of original employment, city residents who give evidence of
qualifications during the application process that are equal to those of nonresident applicants, shall
be given preferential consideration. The city manager shall determine the terms, conditions, scope,
and applicability of this preference.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 66/771
(F) In House Promotion And Transfer Preference: For the purpose of filling employment vacancies,
current employees who provide evidence of minimum or threshold qualifications for a position may
be given preferential consideration over nonemployees with substantially equivalent qualifications.
The preference shall not operate as an absolute preference and the city manager shall establish
the terms, conditions, scope, and applicability of this preference.
(G) Safety: The safety of personnel, conservation of property and the prevention of time and property
loss shall be a basic principle of personnel administration. Each employee and all levels of
management shall support and participate in the implementation of the city's safety policy.
(H) Privacy Of Records: The privacy of personnel records shall be maintained in accordance with
applicable state and federal laws. Affirmative steps shall be taken to prevent the unauthorized
disclosure of personnel information. (Ord. 279, 7-15-1985)
1-6-7: ADMINISTRATION:
Subject to the city council's policy making power to create, reorganize or eliminate departments or
positions, the city manager, as the chief administrative officer of the city, shall administer all of the
personnel policies and procedures of the city, and:
(A) The city manager may, by written administrative order, assign any part or all of the duties and
responsibilities of this chapter to designated staff members. The actions of the staff member under
these circumstances shall have the same force and effect as if taken by the city manager.
(B) The city manager may promulgate written supplemental rules, regulations, or orders to implement
the purposes, intent, policies, or procedures of this chapter.
(C) Any questions concerning the applicability of this chapter shall be interpreted and resolved by the
city manager, with the advice and consultation of the city attorney and any other person deemed
appropriate by the city manager.
(D) The city manager, or the city manager's designee, shall represent the city council in the
negotiation of collectively bargained labor agreements between organized employee groups and
the city:
1. City council members shall not be involved in the negotiation of collective bargaining
agreements.
2. No contract nor agreement regarding the employment or working conditions of any bargaining
unit of organized employees shall be valid unless specifically approved by the city council.
(E) The city manager may employ the services of a professional or other consultant for assistance in
matters of personnel administration or labor relations; provided, however, that the use of these
services shall comply with all city policies governing the use of consultants.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 67/771
(F) Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the city council, city manager, or
department directors from establishing work rules and procedures that are additional to, but
consistent with, the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
1-6-8: DEPARTMENTAL ORGANIZATION:
The administrative service of the city shall be divided under the city manager into such departments
and divisions as the city manager shall determine, by administrative order. Each department and
division shall have such supervisors as prescribed by the city manager; provided, however, that such
employment shall be consistent with the budget as approved by the city council:
(A) Departmental Classification: In establishing departments, consideration shall be given to the kinds
of functions performed, their similarities to other functions, the numbers and abilities of personnel,
workload, and commonly recognized principles of organization and methods; provided, however,
that nothing herein shall be construed to prevent, restrict, or inhibit the use of new or innovative
techniques.
(B) Department Directors; Power And Authority: Department directors shall have the power and
authority given them by statute, this chapter, and delegation from the city manager. They may
promulgate departmental rules and regulations consistent with this chapter or the regulations
promulgated by the city manager.
(C) Department Directors; Responsibility To City Manager: Department directors shall be responsible
to the city manager for the effective administration of their respective departments and all activities
assigned thereto. They shall submit such reports of departmental activities as the city manager
shall require. They shall establish and maintain a system of records in sufficient detail to furnish
information necessary for proper control of departmental activities. They shall be responsible for
the property and equipment assigned to their departments.
(D) Department Directors; Duty Of Cooperation With Other City Departments: Each department
director, and their subordinate employees, shall cooperate with other city departments and shall
furnish services, labor, or materials as requested and as resources, manpower, priorities, and work
schedules permit, subject to the authorization of the city manager. (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
1-6-9: STAFFING LEVELS:
The city manager, as the chief administrative officer of the city, shall determine the employment needs
of the city; provided, however, that such employment shall be consistent with the budget as approved
by the city council:
(A) By administrative order, a position classification plan shall be established and maintained for all
positions covered by this chapter. Separate position classification plans may also be established
and maintained for part time, temporary, or provisional employees.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 68/771
(B) Positions shall be grouped in classes that have a definite range of knowledge, skills, abilities,
required effort, working conditions and responsibility. The city manager shall create a new class
and cause an appropriate class specification to be written whenever a new position is created for
which there is no appropriate class.
(C) The city manager may fill position vacancies within any classification plan through recruitment,
promotion, demotion, transfer, recall, or provisional appointment. Special knowledge, skills,
abilities, required effort, and experience may be required by the city manager for particular
positions.
(D) The city manager shall present the position classification plan to the city council each year for
comment, review, and formal approval by resolution. (Ord. 266, 6-4-1984)
1-6-10: CRIMINAL HISTORY BACKGROUND CHECKS:
(A) The Burnsville police department is authorized to do a criminal history background check
investigation on applicants for city employment and volunteer positions, and
contractors/consultants hired to provide services to the city. Background investigations of
contractors/consultants will only be done if they have access to sensitive city systems and
information such as security information and private data. Before the investigation is undertaken,
the applicant/individual must authorize the police department in writing to undertake the
investigation and to release the information to the city council, city manager, and other city staff as
appropriate. Should the city reject the applicant/individual due, partially or solely, to the
applicant/individual's prior conviction of a crime, the citymanager shall notify the
applicant/individual in writing of the following:
1. The grounds and reason for denial;
2. The applicable complaint and grievance procedure set forth in Minnesota statutes section
364.06;
3. The earliest date the applicant/individual may reapply for employment; and
4. That all competent evidence of rehabilitation will be considered upon reapplication. (Ord. 1098,
10-15-2007)
Chapter 7
ELECTIONS
1-7-1: ADMINISTRATION:
Except as specified herein, all elections within the city shall be conducted pursuant to Minnesota
election law as referenced by Minnesota statutes section 200.01. (Ord. 1233, 4-19-2011)
1-7-2: ESTABLISHMENT OF ABSENTEE BALLOT BOARD:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 69/771
The council hereby establishes an absentee ballot board in the city. Said absentee ballot board will
encompass the entire city for the purpose of receiving all absentee ballots for any primary or general
election, or special referendum held within the municipality. The absentee ballot board shall be under
the direct charge and supervision of the city clerk, and the place for receiving and examining all
returned absentee ballots shall be at the Burnsville city hall, Burnsville, MN 55337. (Ord. 1233, 4-19-
2011)
1-7-3: COMPOSITION AND DUTIES:
Said absentee ballot board shall consist of an election board designated by the city clerk in
accordance with law. The board's duties shall be as specified by law. (Ord. 1233, 4-19-2011)
1-7-4: SPECIAL ELECTION TO FILL COUNCIL VACANCY:
If a council vacancy occurs and a special election to fill the unexpired term is required pursuant to
Minnesota statutes section 412.02, subdivision 2a, and there are more than three hundred sixty five
(365) days until the next general election, then the special election to fill the vacancy shall be held
prior to the general election. The council may by resolution establish the dates of filing affidavits of
candidacy for the office, the time for absentee balloting, and the dates of the special election, as well
as other provisions for the effective administration of the elections. Notwithstanding chapter 11 of this
title, there shall not be a special primary election conducted in association with the special election to
fill the unexpired term. (Ord. 1233, 4-19-2011)
Chapter 8
CODE OF ETHICS
1-8-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
The proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials be independent, impartial
and responsible to the people; that governmental decisions and policy be made in the proper
channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and, that the
public has confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby
established a Code of Ethics for public officials. The purpose of this Code is to establish ethical
standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible
with the best interests of the City, and by directing disclosure by such officials of private, financial or
other interest in matters affecting the City. The provisions and purpose of this Code and such rules
and regulations as may be established are hereby declared to be in the best interests of the City. (Ord.
235, 12-21-81)
1-8-2: ETHICS IN GOVERNMENT:
Minnesota Statutes, chapter 10A, Ethics in Government, is incorporated herein by reference. (Ord.
462, 9-8-92)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 70/771
1-8-3 through 1-8-15: (Rep. by Ord. 462, 9-8-92)
1-8-16: PERSONAL CONFLICTS OF PUBLIC OFFICIALS:
Any public official who has a potential conflict of interest, as defined in this Chapter, shall publicly
disclose the conflict before taking part in any action, discussion or vote pertaining to the matter. This
provision shall not be interpreted to permit any act otherwise prohibited by law. (Ord. 235, 12-21-81)
1-8-17: GIFTS AND FAVORS:
No public official shall accept any valuable gift, whether in the form of money, service, loan, thing or
promise from any person which to the official's knowledge is concerned, directly or indirectly, in any
manner whatsoever in business dealings with the City; nor shall any public official:
(A) Accept any gift, favor or thing of value that may tend to influence the official in the discharge of the
official's duties; or
(B) Grant in the discharge of the official's duties any improper favor, service or thing of value, or
accept an offer which would not have been given if the official were not an official; or
(C) Accept or receive anything of value through sale or gift of goods or services which would result
directly or indirectly from the official's position as a public official of the City. (Ord. 235, 12-21-81)
1-8-18: USE OF CITY EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES:
No public official shall request or permit the unauthorized use of City-owned vehicles, equipment,
materials, property, labor or services for personal convenience or profit. (Ord. 235, 12-21-81)
1-8-19: DISTRIBUTION OF INFORMATION TO OFFICIALS:
The City Clerk shall distribute a copy of this Chapter to every public official within thirty (30) days after
enactment of these sections. The City Clerk shall also distribute a copy of this Chapter to every
subsequently elected or appointed public official within fourteen (14) days of the public official's
election or appointment to public office, and every candidate for City office upon the candidate's filing
for office. (Ord. 235, 12-21-81)
Chapter 9
DEFERRED SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS
1-9-1: DEFERRED SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS PROVIDED:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 71/771
The Council may defer the payment of any special assessment on homestead property owned by a
person who is sixty five (65) years of age or older, or retired by reason of permanent and total
disability, or a member of the Minnesota National Guard (or other military reserves) ordered into active
military service when payment of the assessment would create a hardship upon the property owner as
defined herein. Only special assessments for public improvements are eligible for deferment
consideration. Special assessments for Code enforcement violations and delinquent service charges
such as streetscape operation and maintenance and utility bills shall not be eligible for special
assessment deferment. The deferment shall be granted upon a certification by the owner on the form
prescribed by the County auditor supplemented by the City Clerk to establish the qualification of the
owner for such deferment. The application shall be made within thirty (30) days after the adoption of
the assessment roll by the Council and shall be renewed each following year upon the filing of a
similar application not later than September 30. The Council shall either grant or deny the deferment.
Compounding interest at the current rate for special assessments shall be included with all special
assessment deferrals. If the Council grants the deferment, the Clerk shall notify the County auditor
who shall, in accordance with Minnesota Statutes section 435.194, record a notice of the deferment
with the County Recorder setting forth the amount of the assessment. (Ord. 1446, 1-16-2018)
1-9-2: EXCEPTIONS; CONSIDERATION:
A hardship shall be deemed prima facie to exist when all of the following apply:
(A) The total annual special assessment amount exceeds one percent (1%) of the adjusted gross
income of the applicant and spouse according to their most recent Federal Income Tax return. If
no such return was made, the Clerk shall require the applicant to submit other pertinent
information to show that this qualification is met.
Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the City Council may consider exceptional and unusual
circumstances pertaining to an applicant not covered by foregoing standards; but any determination
shall be made in a nondiscriminatory manner and shall not give the applicant an unreasonable
preference or advantage over other applicants. (Ord. 1446, 1-16-2018)
1-9-3: DISABILITY PROVISION:
Retirement by reason of permanent and total disability shall be deemed prima facie to exist when the
applicant presents a sworn affidavit by a licensed medical doctor attesting that the applicant is unable
to be gainfully employed because of a permanent and total disability. (Ord. 926, 6-21-2004)
1-9-4: DEFERMENT TERMINATION:
The option to defer the payment of special assessments shall terminate and all amounts accumulated
plus applicable interest shall become due upon the occurrence of any one of the following events:
(A) The death of the owner when there is no spouse who is eligible for deferment;
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 72/771
(B) The sale, transfer or subdivision of all or any part of the property;
(C) Loss of homestead status on the property;
(D) The City determines the owner or owner's spouse no longer qualifies for the deferral (return from
military duty);
(E) Determination by the Council for any reason that there would be no hardship to require immediate
or partial payment; or
(F) Failure to file a renewal application within the time prescribed by section 1-9-1 of this chapter.
Upon the occurrence of one of the events specified in this section, the Council shall terminate the
deferment. Thereupon, the City Clerk shall notify the County Assessor and the County auditor of the
termination, including the amounts accumulated on unpaid installments plus applicable interest which
shall become due and payable as a result of the termination. (Ord. 1310, 12-17-2013)
Chapter 10
INFRASTRUCTURE TRUST FUND
1-10-1: FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created a separate dedicated fund designated the infrastructure trust fund. This fund,
including earnings on fund balances, shall be maintained and administered by the city's chief financial
officer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1187, 1-5-2010)
1-10-2: PURPOSE OF FUND:
The fund may only be used to pay for the cost of replacing streets and park infrastructure in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Park infrastructure includes: playground equipment,
lighting, fencing, bituminous pavement, warming houses, shelters, bridges and docks. (Ord. 1187, 1-5-
2010)
1-10-3: EXPENDITURE LIMITATIONS:
(A) The fund may not be used for general maintenance or repairs.
(B) Funds may only be expended on capital projects with a minimum usable life of at least fifteen (15)
years.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 73/771
(C) The fund may only be used for infrastructure replacement.
(D) The fund may not be used for a project unless the project has been included in the city adopted
capital improvement plan for at least two (2) years.
(E) The fund may not be used to displace traditional funding sources for specific projects. (Ord. 1187,
1-5-2010)
1-10-4: PROCEDURE FOR USING FUNDS:
Expenditures from the fund may be made only after compliance with the following procedures:
(A) The city council must hold a public hearing on whether the proposed project should be funded.
Notice specifying the date, time, and place of the hearing, the project to be funded, and the amount
of funding must be published at least ten (10) days before the hearing in the city's official
newspaper.
(B) The city council must make the following findings which shall be incorporated into an adopted
resolution:
1. The project has community benefit.
2. The project could not otherwise be reasonably funded by traditional sources of revenue. (Ord.
1187, 1-5-2010)
1-10-5: FUNDING:
The city council shall annually appropriate money from a tax levy or other available source to fund the
infrastructure trust fund. The appropriated money shall be deposited in the fund. This annual
appropriation shall be in addition to any earnings on fund assets. The annual tax levy proceeds
committed to this fund will not exceed the annual replacement needs. Funding shall be provided at a
level to support pay-go for annual use of funds. Use of funds is set by the city council through the five
(5) year capital improvement plan. Bonding may be considered from time to time, but only in very
limited situations and a plan must exist for the fund that is based on a pay-go strategy over the long
term. (Ord. 1187, 1-5-2010)
1-10-6: FUND BALANCE:
The city council shall annually review the fund balance in the infrastructure trust fund. The fund
balance shall be maintained at a level necessary to maintain a stable tax levy, allow flexibility to deal
with projects that were not anticipated in the five (5) year CIP but included at least for two (2) years in
the CIP. The minimum goal for annual year end dollar amount of fund balance in the infrastructure
trust fund shall be at the discretion of the city council. The city council shall annually adopt a five (5)
year financial plan for the infrastructure trust fund and this plan shall include estimates for fund
balance. (Ord. 1187, 1-5-2010)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 74/771
Chapter 11
PRIMARY ELECTIONS
1-11-1: PRIMARY ELECTION CANDIDATES:
The city primary election and general election for mayor and city council shall be conducted in the
manner provided by law for elections for nonpartisan offices. A primary election for an office shall only
be held if there are a number of candidates equal to more than twice the number of individuals to be
elected to the office. All candidates for mayor and city council shall run for nomination in the city
primary election. (Ord. 996, 10-17-2005)
1-11-2: TIMING OF PRIMARY ELECTIONS:
The dates of the city primary election and the opening and closing dates for the filing of candidates
shall be those established and required in Minnesota statutes chapter 205. For special elections, the
city council shall by resolution fix and determine the dates for the special primary election and the
opening and closing dates for the filing of candidates for office. (Ord. 1233, 4-19-2011)
1-11-3: RESULTS:
Within two (2) days after the primary, the city council shall canvass the returns, and the two (2)
candidates for each office who receive the highest number of votes, or a number of candidates equal
to twice the number of individuals to be elected to the office, who receive the highest number of votes,
shall be the nominees for the office named. (Ord. 996, 10-17-2005)
1-11-4: RECOUNT:
A losing candidate may request a recount of the primary votes for that nomination subject to the
requirements of Minnesota statutes, section 204C.36. (Ord. 996, 10-17-2005)
Chapter 12
FACILITIES CAPITAL FUND
1-12-1: FUND CREATED:
There is hereby created a separate dedicated fund designated the Facilities Capital Fund. This fund,
including earnings on fund balances, shall be maintained and administered by the City's Finance
Officer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1413, 5-2-2017)
1-12-2: PURPOSE OF FUND:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 75/771
The fund may only be used to pay for the cost of capital maintenance, renovation, improvement and
replacement of the City's facilities in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1413, 5-2-
2017)
1-12-3: EXPENDITURE LIMITATIONS:
(A) The fund may not be used for general maintenance or repairs but may be used for capital repairs
and renovations.
(B) Funds may only be expended on capital projects with a minimum usable life of at least ten (10)
years.
(C) The fund may only be used for capital maintenance, renovation, improvement and replacement of
the City's facilities.
(D) The fund may not be used for a project unless the project has been included in the City adopted
capital improvement plan for at least two (2) years.
(E) The fund may not be used to displace traditional funding sources for specific projects. (Ord. 1413,
5-2-2017)
1-12-4: PROCEDURE FOR USING FUNDS:
Expenditures from the fund may be made only after compliance with the following procedures:
(A) The City Council must make the following findings which shall be incorporated into the adopted
capital plan:
1. The project has community benefit.
2. The project could not otherwise be reasonably funded by enterprise funds or other sources of
revenue. (Ord. 1413, 5-2-2017)
1-12-5: FUNDING:
The proceeds from the City's gas and electric utility franchise fees shall be dedicated to the Facilities
Capital Fund. The franchise fees may be used to fund facilities projects within this fund or may be
used to fund debt service on bonds issued to fund facilities projects within this fund. For facilities
benefiting from the City's Enterprise Fund activities, the Enterprise Fund shall contribute funding to
this fund for facilities improvement projects in proportion to the benefit received by the Enterprise
Fund.
The City Council may continue to annually appropriate money from a tax levy or other available
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 76/771
source to fund the Facilities Capital Fund to fund capital maintenance on existing facilities. The
appropriated money shall be deposited in the fund. This annual appropriation shall be in addition to
any earnings on fund assets. Funding shall be provided at a level to support pay-go for annual use of
funds. Use of funds is set by the City Council through the five (5) year capital improvement plan.
Bonding may be considered from time to time, but only in very limited situations and a plan must exist
for the fund that is based on a pay-go strategy over the long term. (Ord. 1413, 5-2-2017)
1-12-6: FUND BALANCE:
The City Council shall annually review the fund balance in the Facilities Capital Fund. The fund
balance shall be maintained at a level necessary to maintain a stable tax levy, allow flexibility to deal
with projects that were not anticipated in the five (5) year CIP but included at least for two (2) years in
the CIP. The minimum goal for annual year end dollar amount of fund balance in the Facilities Capital
Fund shall be at the discretion of the City Council. The City Council shall annually adopt a five (5) year
financial plan for the Facilities Capital Fund and this plan shall include estimates for fund balance.
(Ord. 1413, 5-2-2017)
Title 2
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND DEPARTMENTS
Chapter 1
PLANNING COMMISSION
2-1-1: PURPOSE:
The planning commission shall be an advisory body to the city council charged with the responsibility
of researching, reviewing and making recommendations on issues related to land use and
development in the city. (Ord. 203, 3-17-1980)
2-1-2: COMPOSITION:
(A) The planning commission shall consist of five (5) regular members and one alternate member to
be appointed by the city council. The alternate may vote when there are four (4) or fewer regular
members present.
(B) Appointments shall be made annually by the council on or before June 1 and all members shall be
appointed for a three (3) year term; however, said term may be terminated earlier by the council.
Said terms are to commence on June 1. Midterm vacancies shall be temporarily filled by the
alternate until a regular member has been appointed by the council. The alternate shall apply and
be considered for regular membership along with any other applicants when the city council fills
the vacant regular member position. Every appointed member shall, before entering upon the
discharge of his/her duties, take an oath that he/she will faithfully discharge the duties of the office.
All members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 905, 1-20-2004)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 77/771
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION, MEETINGS:
(A) The commission shall elect a chairperson from amongst its appointed regular members for a term
of one year, and the commission may create and fill such other offices as it may determine. A
quorum shall consist of three (3) members. (Ord. 577, 7-17-1995)
(B) The commission shall hold at least two (2) regular meetings each month. These meetings shall be
held on the second and fourth Mondays. Meetings shall commence at six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M.,
and hearings shall be heard at six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M., or as soon thereafter as possible. Any
regular meeting falling upon a holiday shall be held on the next following business day at the same
time and place. Additional meetings may be scheduled by the commission as required. (Ord. 1170,
7-21-2009, eff. 8-1-2009)
(C) The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its
resolutions, transactions and findings, which records shall be a public record. (Ord. 577, 7-17-
1995)
Chapter 2
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
2-2-1: POLICY AND PURPOSE:
Because of the existing possibility of the occurrence of disasters of unprecedented size and
destruction resulting from fire, flood, tornado, blizzard, destructive winds or other natural causes, or
from sabotage, hostile action, or from hazardous material mishaps of catastrophic measure; and in
order to ensure that preparations of the city of Burnsville will be adequate to deal with such disasters,
and generally, to provide for the common defense and to protect the public peace, health, and safety,
and to preserve the lives and property of the people of the city of Burnsville, it is hereby found and
declared to be necessary:
(A) To establish a city emergency management organization responsible for planning and preparation
for emergency government operations in time of disasters.
(B) To provide for the exercise of necessary powers during emergencies and disasters.
(C) To provide for the rendering of mutual aid between the city of Burnsville and other political
subdivisions of this state and of other states with respect to the carrying out of emergency
preparedness functions.
(D) To comply with provisions of Minnesota statutes, chapter 12, section 12.25, which requires that
each political subdivision of Minnesota shall establish a local organization for emergency
management. (Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 78/771
2-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
DISASTER: A situation which creates an immediate and serious impairment to the health and safety
of any person, or a situation which has resulted in or is likely to result in catastrophic loss to property,
and for which traditional sources of relief and assistance within the affected area are unable torepair
or prevent the injury or loss.
EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances which calls for immediate action to
prevent from developing or occurring.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: The preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency functions,
other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair
injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by fire, flood, tornado and other acts of nature, or
from sabotage, hostile action, or from industrial hazardous material mishaps. These functions include,
without limitation, firefighting services, police services, emergency medical services, engineering,
warning services, communications, radiological and chemical, evacuation, congregate care,
emergency transportation, existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection, temporary
restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civil protection, together with all other
activities necessary or incidental for carrying out the foregoing functions. Emergency management
includes those activities sometimes referred to as "civil defense" functions.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT FORCES: The total personnel resources engaged in city level
emergency management functions in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or any rule or
order thereunder. This includes personnel from city departments, authorized volunteers, and private
organizations and agencies.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATION: The staff element responsible for coordinating city
level planning and preparation for disaster response. This organization provides city liaison and
coordination with federal, state and local jurisdictions relative to disaster preparedness activities and
assures implementation of federal and state program requirements. (Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-3: ESTABLISHMENT OF AN EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATION:
There is hereby created within the city of Burnsville government an emergency management
organization that shall be under the supervision and control of the emergency management director,
hereinafter called the "director". The director shall be designated by the city manager for an indefinite
term and may be removed by the city manager at any time. The director shall have direct
responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the emergency preparedness
organization, subject to the direction and control of the city manager. An emergency management
coordinator, hereinafter called the "coordinator" may be designated to assist the director in fulfilling
emergency management duties. (Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-4: POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR:
(A) The director shall act as principal aide and advisor to thecity official responsible for direction and
control of all city emergency operations during an emergency. The coordinator's main responsibility
is to assure coordination among the operating departments, nongovernmental groups, and with
higher and adjacent governments.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 79/771
(B) The director, with the consent of the city manager, shall represent the city of Burnsville on any
regional or state conference for emergency management.
(C) The director shall develop proposed mutual aid agreements with other political subdivisions of the
state for reciprocal emergency management aid and assistance in an emergency too great to be
dealt with unassisted, and shall present such agreements to the city council for its action. Such
arrangements shall be consistent with the state emergency plan.
(D) The director shall make studies and surveys of the manpower, industries, resources and facilities
of the city as deemed necessary to determine their adequacy for emergency management and to
plan for their most efficient use in time of an emergency or disaster.
(E) The director shall prepare a comprehensive emergency plan, consistent with the national incident
management system, for the emergency preparedness of the city, including municipal and
unincorporated areas and shall present such plan to the city council for its approval. When the
council has approved the plan by resolution, it shall be the duty of all city departments and all
emergency preparedness forces of the city to perform the duties and functions assigned by the
plan as approved. The plan may be modified in like manner from time to time. The director shall
coordinate the emergency management activities of the city to the end that they shall be consistent
and fully integrated with the emergency plan of the federal government and the state and
correlated with emergency plans of other political subdivisions within the state.
(F) In accordance with the state and county emergency plan, the director shall institute such training
programs, public information programs and conduct practice warning alerts and emergency
exercises as may be necessary to assure prompt and effective operation of the Burnsville
emergency operations plan when a disaster occurs.
(G) The director shall utilize the personnel, services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing
departments and agencies of the county to the maximum extent practicable. The officers and
personnel of all such departments and agencies shall, to the maximum extent practicable,
cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the city emergency management
organization and to the governor upon request. The head of each department or agency in
cooperation with the director shall be responsible for the planning and programming of such
emergency activities as will involve the utilization of the facilities of the department or agency.
(H) The director shall, in cooperation with existing city departments and agencies affected, assist in
the organizing, recruiting and training of such emergency management personnel, that may be
required on a volunteer basis to carry out the emergency plans of the city and state. To the extent
that such emergency personnel are recruited to augment a regular city department or agency for
emergencies, they shall be assigned to such departments or agencies and shall be under the
administration and control of said department or agency.
(I) The director shall carry out all orders, rules and regulations issued by the governor with reference
to emergency management.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 80/771
(J) The director shall prepare and submit such reports on emergency preparedness activities as may
be requested by the city council/city manager. (Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-5: LOCAL EMERGENCIES:
(A) A local emergency may be declared only by the mayor or the mayor's legal successors. It shall not
be continued for a period in excess of three (3) days except by or with the consent of the governing
board of the political subdivision. Any order, or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a
local emergency shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly by the city
clerk's office.
(B) A declaration of a local emergency shall invoke necessary portions of the response and recovery
aspects of applicable local or interjurisdictional disaster plans, and may authorize aid and
assistance thereunder.
(C) No jurisdictional agency or official may declare a local emergency unless expressly authorized by
the agreement under which the agency functions. However, an interjurisdictional disaster agency
shall provide aid and services in accordance with the agreement under which it functions. (Ord.
1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-6: EMERGENCY REGULATIONS:
(A) Whenever necessary to meet a declared emergency or to prepare for such an emergency for
which adequate regulations have not been adopted by the governor or the city council, the council
may by resolution promulgate regulations, consistent with applicable federal or state law or
regulation, respecting: the conduct of persons and the use of property during emergencies; the
repair, maintenance, and safeguarding of essential public services, emergency health, fire, and
safety regulation, drills, or practice periods required for preliminary training, and all other matters
which are required to protect public safety, health, and welfare in declared emergencies.
(B) Every resolution of emergency regulations shall be inwriting: shall be dated; shall refer to the
particular emergency to which it pertains, if so limited, and shall be filed in the city clerk's office,
which copy shall be kept posted and available for public inspection during business hours. Notice
of the existence of such regulation and its availability for inspection at the clerk's office shall be
conspicuously posted at the front of the city hall or other headquarters of the city or at such other
places in the affected area as the mayor shall designate.
(C) The city council may rescind any such regulation by resolution at any time. If not sooner rescinded
every such regulation shall expire at the end of thirty (30) days after its effective date or at the end
of the emergency to which it relates, whichever comes first. Any resolution, rule, or regulation
inconsistent with an emergency regulation promulgated by the council shall be suspended during
the period of time and to the extent such conflict exists.
(D) During a declared emergency, the city is, notwithstanding any statutory or charter provision to the
contrary, empowered, through its governing body acting within or without the corporate limits of the
city, to enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to combat such disaster by protecting
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 81/771
the health and safety of persons and property and providing emergency assistance to the victims
of such disaster. The city may exercise such powers in the light of the exigencies of the disaster
without compliance with the time consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law
pertaining to the performance of public work, entering rental equipment agreements, purchase of
supplies and materials, limitations upon tax levies, and the appropriation and expenditure of public
funds including, but not limited to, publication of resolutions, publication of call for bids, provisions
of personnel laws and rules, provisions relating to low bids, and requirement for budgets. (Ord.
1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-7: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT A GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTION:
All functions thereunder and all other activities relating to emergency management are hereby
declared to be governmental functions. The provisions of this section shall not affect the right of any
person to receive benefits to which he would otherwise be entitled under this chapter or under the
workers' compensation law, or under any pension law, nor the right of any such person to receive any
benefits or compensation under any act of congress. (Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-8: PARTICIPATION IN LABOR DISPUTE OR POLITICS:
The emergency management organization shall not participate in any form of political activity, nor shall
it be employed directly or indirectly for political purposes, nor shall it be employed in a labor dispute.
(Ord. 1000, 10-17-2005)
2-2-9: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall be effective immediately upon its passage and publication according to law. (Ord.
1000, 10-17-2005)

Chapter 4
POLICE DEPARTMENT
2-4-1: CREATION:
There is hereby established a city police department. (Ord. 233, 11-2-1981)
2-4-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 82/771
The department shall be under the direction and supervision of a chief of police, subject to the general
supervision of the manager. (Ord. 233, 11-2-1981)
2-4-3: PURPOSE:
The department shall be responsible for the preservation of public peace and order, the prevention
and detection of crime, the apprehension of offenders, the protection of persons and property and the
enforcement of state laws and city ordinances, and the rendering of emergency services. (Ord. 233,
11-2-1981)
2-4-4: PERSONNEL:
The council shall determine the number of persons serving in the department as full time professional
police officers or as participants in special police programs. (Ord. 233, 11-2-1981)
2-4-5: RECORDS:
The chief of police shall supervise and control the city's participation in any state or federal criminal
justice data communication network and shall be responsible for the collection, use, access to and
dissemination of all police law enforcement data as defined by the Minnesota government data
practices act. (Ord. 233, 11-2-1981)
2-4-6: CRIMINAL HISTORY BACKGROUND CHECKS:
(A) Purpose: The purpose and intent of this section is to establish regulations that will allow law
enforcement access to Minnesota's computerized criminal history information for specified
noncriminal purposes of conducting criminal history background checks for city licenses, permits,
registrations or other approvals.
(B) Criminal History Background Investigations: The police department is hereby authorized, as the
exclusive entity within the city, to do a criminal history background investigation on the applicants
for city permits, licenses, registrations and other approvals.
In conducting the criminal history background investigation in order to screen applicants, the police
department is authorized to access data maintained in the Minnesota bureau of criminal
apprehensions computerized criminal history information system in accordance with BCA policy.
Any data that is accessed and acquired shall be maintained at the police department under the
care and custody of the chief law enforcement official or his or her designee. A summary of the
results of the computerized criminal history data may be released by the police department to the
approving authority, including the city council, the city manager, or other city staff involved in the
license or permit approval or registration process.
Before the investigation is undertaken, the applicant must authorize the police department by
written consent to undertake the investigation. The written consent must fully comply with the
provisions of Minnesota statutes chapter 13 regarding the collection, maintenance and use of the
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 83/771
information. Except for the positions set forth in Minnesota statutes section 364.09, the city will not
reject an applicant for a license on the basis of the applicant's prior conviction unless the crime is
directly related to the license sought and the conviction is for a felony, gross misdemeanor, or
misdemeanor with a jail sentence. If the city rejects the applicant's request on this basis, the city
shall notify the applicant in writing of the following:
1. The grounds and reasons for the denial.
2. The applicant complaint and grievance procedure set forth in Minnesota statutes section 364.06.
3. The earliest date the applicant may reapply for the license.
4. That all competent evidence of rehabilitation will be considered upon reapplication. (Ord. 1271,
7-17-2012)

supported relief association or similar organization shall be created to provide pensions, annuities or

Chapter 6
PARKS AND NATURAL RESOURCES COMMISSION
2-6-1: PURPOSE:
(A) The Parks and Natural Resources Commission is an advisory body to the City Council. The
mission of the Parks and Natural Resources Commission is:
1. To advise the City Council and staff on parks and natural resources issues.
2. To guide the development, improvement, renovation and management of our park system.
3. To advocate the responsible use, preservation and enhancement of our natural resources.
(B) The Commission is responsible for the following specific duties related to the accomplishment of
the mission:
1. Preparing and recommending updates to the parks master plan and the natural resources
master plan to the City Council.
2. Providing a forum for citizen input.
3. Reviewing City policies, regulations and plans as relevant to the nature of the Commission.
4. Involvement with the development review process as appropriate. (Ord. 802, 7-17-2000)
2-6-2: COMPOSITION:
The Parks and Natural Resources Commission shall consist of seven (7) members, one alternate
member, and two (2) youth members occupying one of the seven (7) seats, to be appointed by the
City Council. No member of the Parks and Natural Resources Commission shall hold any other public
office in the City.
Appointments shall be made annually by the Council on June 1, and all members shall be appointed
for a three (3) year term; however, said term may be terminated earlier by the Council. Exception:
Youth members shall be appointed on March 1, and shall be appointed for a one year term. Vacancies
shall be filled by the Council for the unexpired portion of the term. Every appointed member shall,
before entering upon thedischarge of duties, take an oath that the member will faithfully discharge the
duties of the office. All members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 802, 7-17-2000)
