Chapter 30
MOBILE VENDING (IN ROW ONLY)
3-30-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter, the following words shall have the
meanings given to them by this section:
MOBILE VENDOR: A person, firm or corporation in the business of selling food, goods, wares or
merchandise from a vehicle, trailer, or cart within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose,
temporarily or periodically hires, leases, uses or occupies any street or right of way.
PERSON: Any natural individual, group, organization, corporation, partnership, or similar association.
(Ord. 1297, 4-16-2013)
3-30-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any mobile vendor to engage in any such activity within the city without first obtaining
a license from the city in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Mobile vendors licensed under
this chapter do not need city issued peddlers or transient merchant licenses when operating on streets
or rights of way. Licensure under this chapter does not exempt compliance with all other applicable
local, state, and federal laws. Vendors operating within the city other than on streets or rights of way
must register as transient merchants or peddlers and meet any land use or other official controls.
Licenses shall be valid for the calendar year and shall not be prorated for part of a year. All licenses
shall expire on December 31 after their issue. A license may not be transferred. (Ord. 1297, 4-16-
2013)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 193/771
3-30-3: LICENSE APPLICATION:
Persons seeking a license under this chapter shall file with the city a written application on a form to
be furnished by the city. The application shall provide:
(A) A description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold and the license plate number
and description for any vehicle to be used in conjunction with the activity. If selling food, a copy of
the department of health or department of agriculture license must be submitted with the
application. The application shall also include the following information for the owner/operator of
the mobile vendor business as well as for all persons working for or assisting the owner/operator of
the mobile vending business;
(B) The applicant's full legal name, other names the applicant uses or is known by, date of birth and
driver's license number or other acceptable identification of the person registering;
(C) The permanent and any temporary home and business address, phone numbers, and e-mail
address of the applicant;
(D) A recent color photograph of the applicant which picture shall be approximately two inches by two
inches (2" x 2") showing the head and shoulders of the person in a clear and distinguishing
manner;
(E) The names of at least two (2) references who will substantiate the person's good character and
business respectability or other evidence of the good character and business responsibility of the
person;
(F) A statement as to whether or not the person has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or
violation of any municipal ordinance, other than traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the
punishment or penalty assessed, written authorization for the city to conduct a criminal history
background check, and acknowledgment that failure to disclose previous convictions will disqualify
the applicant;
(G) The two (2) preceding municipalities, if any, where the person carried on his or her activity prior to
the current application.
(H) Before any license will be issued allowing vending in the public right of way, the applicant shall
provide a certificate of insurance or self-insurance:
1. Verifying that an insurance policy has been issued to the applicant by an insurance company
authorized to do business in the state of Minnesota, or a form of self-insurance acceptable to the
city;
2. Verifying that the applicant is insured against claims arising out of all operations of such
applicant under this chapter for the sum of at least two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) against
liability for bodily injuries to one person from the accident, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for
the injury of two (2) or more persons, and for at least two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) against
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 194/771
liability for damage or destruction of property, or such amounts at least to the limits of liability
established by Minnesota statutes section 466.04;
3. Naming the city as an additional insured as to whom the coverages required herein are in force
and applicable and for whom defense will be provided as to all such coverages;
4. Requiring that the city be notified thirty (30) days in advance of cancellation of the policy or
material modification of a coverage term.
(I) City may require a copy of the insurance policy. If the insurance is canceled or suspended and the
licensee fails to replace the same with another policy conforming to the provisions of this section,
the license shall be automatically suspended until the insurance is reinstated or replaced. (Ord.
1297, 4-16-2013)
3-30-4: FEE:
(A) License Fee: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the person applying for the license shall
pay a fee to cover the administrative costs of processing and investigation at the time of
application. The fee shall be in an amount determined by council resolution or ordinance and is not
refundable if the license is denied or applicant withdraws or otherwise ceases operation or use of
the license. (Ord. 1297, 4-16-2013)
3-30-5: LICENSE POSTED:
The city shall issue a mobile vendor license upon the filing of a properly signed and completed form
and satisfactory completion of the investigation and criminal history background check for the
applicant and for all persons working for or assisting the owner/operator of the mobile vending
business. All mobile vendors shall post their city license on or in the vehicle, trailer or cart as to be
visible by the purchasing public. (Ord. 1297, 4-16-2013)
3-30-6: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
(A) Regulations: A person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall be allowed to conduct
activity within the city; provided, that none of the following occurs:
1. Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for licensure.
2. Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the activity.
3. Any violation of this chapter.
4. Conviction of any felony, gross misdemeanor, or a misdemeanor or violation of any local
ordinance, which adversely reflects upon the person's ability to conduct the business for which
the license is being sought in a professional, honest and legal manner. Such violations shall
include, but are not limited to, burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business
practices, and any form of actual or threatened physical harm against another person.
5. Conducting the business in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of
the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public,
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 195/771
including revocation of any state license or authority to operate such business.
6. Conducting the business in a disreputable manner. Evidence of a bad business reputation shall
include, but is not limited to, the existence of more than three (3) complaints against an applicant
with the Better Business Bureau, the office of the Minnesota attorney general or other state
attorney general's office, or other similar business or consumer rights office or agency, within the
preceding twelve (12) months, or three (3) complaints filed with the city against an applicant
within the preceding five (5) years.
(B) Denial/Revocation: A license shall be denied or revoked if any of the conduct listed in subsection
(A) of this section shall occur.
(C) Notice: Prior to revoking or suspending any license issued under this chapter, the city shall provide
a license holder with written notice of the alleged violations and inform the licensee of his or her
right to a hearing on the alleged violation. Notice shall be delivered in person or by mail to the
permanent residential address listed on the license application, or if no residential address is listed,
to the business address provided on the license application.
(D) Public Hearing: Upon receiving the notice provided in subsection (C) of this section, the licensee
shall have the right to request a public hearing. If no request for a hearing is received by the city
clerk within ten (10) days following the service of the notice, the city may proceed with the
suspension or revocation. For the purpose of a mailed notice, service shall be considered
complete as of the date the notice is placed in the mail. If a public hearing is requested within the
stated time frame, a hearing shall be scheduled within twenty (20) days from the date of the
request for the public hearing. The city manager may designate the neutral hearing officer or board
or may, with the consent of the licensee, hear the matter personally or by his or her designee.
Within three (3) regular business days of the hearing, the city shall notify the licensee of its
decision.
(E) Emergency: If, in the discretion of the city manager or city council, imminent harm to the health or
safety of the public may occur because of the actions of a mobile vendor licensed under this
chapter, the city manager or council may immediately suspend the person's license and provide
notice of the right to hold a subsequent public hearing as prescribed in subsection (C) of this
section.
(F) Appeal: Any person whose license is suspended or revoked under this section shall have the right
to appeal that decision to district court. (Ord. 1297, 4-16-2013)
3-30-7: MOBILE VENDING PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
(A) Mobile vending shall only be permitted in locations identified by the city. Such locations shall not
be on any collector or higher capacity street. Such locations shall not be allowed where the street
is posted "No Parking". Such locations shall not be in areas zoned residential as indicated with R
type zoning on the zoning map. Such locations shall not compete with other events (block parties,
park events, legacy events). All locations are on a first come first serve basis and cannot be
reserved.
Approved locations are as follows:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 196/771
1. Within the on street parking area located on the north side of 126th Street, adjacent to Nicollet
Commons Park, between Nicollet Avenue and Pillsbury Avenue.
2. Within the on street parking area located on the north side of 125th Street between Nicollet
Avenue and 1st Avenue.
(B) For vendors selling food, such locations shall have known facilities for restrooms.
(C) Vendors may also sell in the right of way at any zoning district and location within a registered and
approved block party area or when catering to a private event such as a graduation party.
(D) Mobile vending operations may not take up more than two (2) parking stalls at any time. All traffic,
parking, and right of way laws and regulations shall be complied with.
(E) No mobile vendor shall call attention to his or her business or to his or her merchandise by crying
out, by blowing a horn, by ringing a bell, playing music or other noise discernible beyond the truck
or trailer or cart or by displaying lights, or any sign or device except flat mounted signs affixed to
their vehicle, trailer or cart.
(F) Hours of operation shall be between nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on any
given day. The operator shall have up to an additional thirty (30) minutes before and after these
times for setup and take down.
(G) Mobile vending vehicles, trailers or carts shall not be stored outside and visible on any residential
property. Storage on commercial or industrial properties shall comply with all zoning requirements.
(H) To protect pedestrian safety, mobile vending vehicles and trailers shall have the customer window
or access point facing the curb.
(I) All mobile vending vehicles, trailers and carts shall be self-contained. There shall be no electrical
cords or other utility hookups or exterior hazards to the public.
(J) All mobile food vendors shall provide separate trash and recycling receptacles for their customers.
Vendors shall pick up trash from the area and remove their receptacles when they relocate. (Ord.
1297, 4-16-2013)
Chapter 31
SHORT TERM RENTALS1
3-31-1: FINDINGS AND PURPOSE:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 197/771
(A) The City of Burnsville is committed to maintaining the quality of life and has a compelling interest
in protecting the character of its residential neighborhoods.
(B) Rental of private homes for temporary occupancy is a commercial activity that if unregulated can
change the essential character and stability of residential neighborhoods because short term
tenants have little interest in the welfare of the local community, do not engage in activities that
strengthen residential neighborhoods, and do not integrate into residential neighborhoods.
(C) The unregulated rental of private homes for temporary occupancy can disturb residential
neighborhoods by creating excessive noise, accumulation of refuse, trespassing, disorderly
conduct, vandalism, high occupant turnover, excessive traffic, and excessive numbers of parked
motor vehicles.
(D) Regulating rental of private homes for temporary occupancy is necessary to protect the essential
character of residential neighborhoods and the health, safety, and welfare of the community.
(E) Rental of residential homes for temporary occupancy requires adequate on site management,
compliance with State and local codes for commercial lodging establishments, and other
safeguards for those renting the home. (Ord. 1445, 12-5-2017)
3-31-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms are defined as follows:
ENTERPRISE: Any corporation, association, firm, partnership, limited liability partnership, or other
legal entity.
MANAGING AGENCY OR RENTAL AGENT: A person, enterprise, or agency representing the owner
of the short term home rental unit.
PERSON: An individual or group of individuals.
REMUNERATION: Compensation, money, or other consideration given in return for occupancy,
possession, or use of real property.
RENT: The consideration or remuneration charged whether or not received, for the occupancy of
space in a short term home rental unit, valued in money, whether to be received in money, goods,
labor, or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, property, or services of any kind. Rent may
include consideration or remuneration received pursuant to an option to purchase whereby a person is
given the right to possess the property for a term of less than thirty (30) days.
RENTAL: An arrangement between a transient and a home owner whereby rent is received in
exchange for the right to possess a residential structure.
SHORT TERM HOME RENTAL UNIT: Any structure, or any portion of any structure, that is rented to a
transient for less than thirty (30) consecutive days.
TRANSIENT: Any person who, at their own expense or at the expense of another, exercises
occupancy or possession, or is entitled to occupancy or possession, by reason of any rental
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 198/771
agreement, concession, permit, right of access, option to purchase, license, time sharing
arrangement, or any other type of agreement for a period of less than thirty (30) consecutive calendar
days. (Ord. 1445, 12-5-2017)
3-31-3: SHORT TERM HOME RENTAL AUTHORIZED AND REGULATED:
Rental of all or a portion of a home as a short term rental by a home owner to any transient is allowed
as provided by this section following issuance of a City permit. State licensed hotels, motels and
lodging establishments located outside residential or planned residential development districts are
allowed as provided in title 10 of this Code. Rental of any other properties for residential dwelling unit
purposes for longer than thirty (30) days requires a rental license under chapter 28 of this title.
(A) Only the principal structure or a portion of a principal structure located on property that is classified
and maintained as homestead under State law is eligible for short term home rental.
(B) Property which is rented in whole or in part by the owner requires a permit issued by the City, for
which the City may establish a fee.
(C) Property owners must notify any neighbors abutting to the side, rear or across the street from their
property at the time of permit application and prior to making their property available for short term
rental.
(D) Property must have working smoke and carbon monoxide detectors in each bedroom or sleeping
area and the owner must provide any transient renting the property with information regarding
emergency egress.
(E) The property owner must pay all Federal, State and local taxes, including Local Lodging Tax under
chapter 22 of this title. (Ord. 1445, 12-5-2017)
3-31-4: VIOLATIONS:
(A) Unlawful Acts: It shall be unlawful for a person, firm or corporation to be in conflict with or in
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or other provisions of this Code.
(B) Notice Of Violation: The Code official shall serve a notice of violation or order in accordance with
title 4, chapter 8 of this Code or as required by State Statute.
(C) Prosecution Of Violation: If the notice of violation is not complied with, the Code official shall
institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equality to restrain, correct or abate such violation,
or to require the termination of the unlawful occupancy of the structure in violation of the provisions
of this chapter or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 199/771
(D) Violation Penalties: Any person who shall violate a provision of this chapter, or fail to comply
therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof is guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that a
violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.
Permittees are subject to the provisions of sections 3-28-10 through 3-28-13 of this title and
permits may be revoked or suspended for violations of those sections.
(E) Abatement Of Violation: The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the
City Attorney from instituting appropriate action to restrain, correct or abate a violation, or to
prevent legal occupancy of a building, structure or premises, or to stop an illegal act, conduct,
business or utilization of the building, structure or premises.
(F) Fees And Charges: The property owner of record shall be responsible for any City costs in
enforcing the provisions of this chapter including reinspection fees, civil fines, or other fees,
charges or penalties that are imposed as permitted by law.
(G) Civil Fines: The City Council may impose civil fines pursuant to subsection 3-28-10(C)3 of this
title. (Ord. 1445, 12-5-2017)
Chapter 32
SPECIAL EVENTS
3-32-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for special events including temporary indoor promotional
sales, outdoor promotional sales and residential neighborhood block parties which are distinguished
from permanent outside business activities and temporary seasonal sales. It is the intent of this
section to promote the health, safety, general welfare, aesthetics, and image of the community by
regulating special events. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter, the following words shall have the
meanings given to them by this section:
COMMUNITY EVENT SIGN: A temporary on or off premises sign promoting an event sponsored by or
part of an event sponsored by a school district, athletic association, or the City.
LEGACY EVENT: An annual event that is hosted by a local nonprofit group, which is set up
specifically to manage the event. Legacy Events take place in City parks, and serve a broad
population of the community and are required to meet the criteria listed in City Council Policy 1.027.
LEGACY EVENT BANNER: A temporary on or off premises banner promoting a Legacy Event.
LEGACY EVENT SIGN: A temporary on or off premises sandwich board or freestanding sign
promoting a Legacy Event.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 200/771
RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD BLOCK PARTY: A party held by the residents of a block or
neighborhood by invitation and typically held on a temporarily closed street.
SPECIAL EVENTS: A temporary indoor or outdoor promotional or sales event, residential
neighborhood block party, community event, Legacy Event, civic or religious celebration, school or
daycare registration, or employee celebration or recognition event whether conducted on private
property, public property, or City right-of-way.
TEMPORARY INDOOR PROMOTIONAL OR SALES EVENT: A temporary promotional or sales event
directed toward the general public including only grand openings, storewide sales, craft shows,
registration for daycare, an educational, recreational, civic or religious activity, and community
celebrations.
TEMPORARY OUTDOOR PROMOTIONAL OR SALES EVENT: A temporary promotional or special
event sale directed toward the general public, including only grand opening sales, storewide sales of
materials and products that are typically sold or serviced on the premises, registration for daycare, an
educational, recreational, civic or religious activity, community celebrations, warehouse sales, tent
sales, sidewalk sales, craft shows, flea markets, inventory reduction and liquidation sales, and
mechanical or animal rides.
TEMPORARY SIGN: Any sign which is erected or displayed for a specific period of time, and not of a
permanent nature. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-3: SPECIAL EVENT PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
(A) Temporary Indoor And Outdoor Promotional Sales Events On Private Property: Temporary indoor
and outdoor promotional sales events on private property shall meet the following requirements:
1. Permit Required: No special event shall be held without first obtaining a permit.
2. Number Of Events: The businesses in all business and industrial zoning districts as well as each
public and institutional conditional use in residential districts shall be allowed six (6) temporary
indoor or outdoor promotional or sales event special events per calendar year. Each special
event shall not exceed ten (10) days and shall not be extended for more than three (3)
consecutive time periods for each business. Once the time period has expired for the special
event the business shall wait the same number of days that the permit was issued to start a new
special event.
3. Tents: Including all ties, ropes, stakes, etc., shall be located entirely upon the permittee's
property and shall comply with the City's setback requirements for accessory buildings and all
Building and Fire Codes.
(B) Special Events In The Public Right-of-Way: Special events in the public right-of-way shall meet the
following requirements:
1. One (1) temporary special event in the right-of-way shall be allowed per applicant per year per
street segment.
2. The street closure shall not exceed more than one (1) day and is limited to daylight hours.
3. A permit for events utilizing City right-of-way shall meet the following requirements:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 201/771
a. Shall only be issued on streets with a maximum of two (2) lanes of traffic not including turn
lanes.
b. Must allow property access from at least one (1) direction.
c. Arterials streets are not eligible for temporary closures. Collector streets are at the discretion
of the City Engineer for access and safety review.
d. Must receive permission from all properties immediately adjacent to the street segment being
closed.
e. A twenty foot (20') wide path shall be maintained through the special event boundaries which
may be blocked by barriers that can be moved by hand.
f. Fire hydrants shall not be obstructed.
g. The applicant shall provide an insurance certificate meeting the following requirements:
(1) Verifying that an insurance policy has been issued to the registrant by an insurance
company authorized to do business in the State of Minnesota, or a form of self-insurance
acceptable to the City;
(2) Verifying that the registrant is insured against claims for personal injury, including death, as
well as claims for property damage arising out of the: a) use and occupancy of the right-ofway
by the registrant, its officers, agents, employees and permittees, and b) placement and
use of facilities and equipment in the right-of-way by the registrant, its officers, agents,
employees and permittees, including, but not limited to, protection against liability arising
from completed operations, damage of underground facilities and collapse of property, with
coverage at least to the limits of liability established by Minnesota Statutes section 466.04,
or its successor;
(3) Naming the City as an additional insured as to whom the coverages required herein are in
force and applicable and for whom defense will be provided as to all such coverages;
(4) Requiring that the City be notified thirty (30) days in advance of cancellation of the policy or
material modification of a coverage term;
(5) Indicating comprehensive liability coverage, automobile liability coverage, workers'
compensation and umbrella coverage established by the City in amounts sufficient to
protect the City and the public and to carry out the purposes and policies of this chapter.
h. A cash escrow of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) shall be submitted to the City
to ensure cleanup and restoration of the City's right-of-way to the equivalent of what it was
prior to the event. Upon verification that the site was restored appropriately, the escrow shall
be returned. If the applicant does not restore the site appropriately, as determined by the City
Engineer, within twenty four (24) hours after completion of the event, the City shall use the
escrow to restore the site as necessary.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 202/771
i. Consumption, sales and serving of alcohol shall comply with the requirements set forth in
chapter 1 of this title.
j. Tents, including all ties, ropes, stakes, etc., shall comply with all Building and Fire Codes.
k. All special events shall be subject to the excessive noise requirements in section 10-7-9 of
this Code.
l. Sign regulations and sign permit requirements related to special events are subject to the
requirements outlined in section 3-32-4 of this chapter.
m. Legacy and community events are not subject to this section provided review of the proposed
right-of-way closure is completed by the City Engineer for access and safety.
(C) Residential Neighborhood Block Parties:
1. A permit for events utilizing City right-of-way for residential block parties shall meet the following
requirements:
a. Must receive permission or no objections from all property owners immediately adjacent to the
road being closed or that would be blocked off completely because of the closure.
b. Through streets will be considered for approval on a case-by-case basis.
c. Arterials and collector streets are not eligible for neighborhood block parties.
d. A twenty foot (20') wide path shall be maintained through the special event boundaries on
private property, public property or City right-of-way which may be blocked by barriers that can
be moved by hand.
e. Fire hydrants shall not be obstructed.
f. Block parties permitted under this application are limited to daylight hours.
g. Alcohol shall comply with the requirements set forth in chapter 1 of this title.
h. Tents, including all ties, ropes, stakes, etc., shall comply with all Building and Fire Codes.
i. All special events shall be subject to the excessive noise requirements in section 10-7-9 of this
Code.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 203/771
j. Sign regulations and sign permit requirements related to special events are subject to the
requirements outlined in section 3-32-4 of this chapter.
(D) Permitted Uses: Events, including special events or uses with a park permit as issued by the City
Recreation Department are permitted by title 10, chapter 12B of this Code.
(E) Peddlers; Solicitors; Transient Merchants: Peddlers, solicitors and transient merchants are
permitted by chapter 20 of this title.
(F) Mobile Vending: Mobile vending (in ROW only) is permitted as licensed in chapter 30 of this title.
(Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-4: SPECIAL EVENT SIGNS:
(A) Permitted Advertising Devices For Indoor And Outdoor Promotional Sales Events On Private
Property: Advertising devices for special events must be directly related to the activity being
conducted as a special event. The advertising devices described below are permitted with
approval of a permit for special events in addition to the maximum allowable sign area, provided
they are professionally done and the following standards are met and complied with:
1. Small Balloons:
a. The size of small balloons or a group of connected balloons shall not exceed two feet (2') as
the largest dimension, except that balloon arches extending across streets and private
driveways shall not exceed twenty feet (20') in height. Balloon arches over streets require the
street to be closed.
b. Small balloons may be multicolored and incorporate logos and messages.
c. Helium balloons shall be regularly maintained and refilled.
2. Bannerettes:
a. Bannerettes may be used on light standards or flagpoles.
b. No more than one (1) bannerette shall be allowed per standard or pole.
c. Bannerettes shall be smaller than any U.S. flag on the property, and shall not be flown at a
height greater than any U.S. flag allowed on the property.
3. Banners:
a. Banners may be attached to poles, tents, and buildings, provided they are well secured and
are prevented from being blown around uncontrollably by the wind.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 204/771
b. No more than two (2) banners shall be allowed.
c. Banners shall not be larger than one hundred (100) square feet nor higher than the wall of the
principal building on the lot.
d. All banners shall be maintained such that they do not become ripped, torn, defaced,
damaged, loose, or unsecured.
4. Inflatable Devices:
a. The size of inflatable devices shall not exceed twenty four feet (24') as the largest dimension.
b. Inflatable devices may be multicolored and incorporate logos and messages.
c. Helium inflatable devices shall be refilled daily.
d. Inflatable devices must be anchored or tethered and must be kept in a weathertight and
presentable condition.
e. Inflatable devices may be located on rooftops, in green space, or in parking lot areas.
f. Inflatable devices shall be allowed for one (1) event per business per calendar year and shall
not exceed ten (10) days in duration.
5. Searchlights: Searchlights may be allowed by permit as a temporary use, provided such use
shall not exceed a duration of three (3) consecutive days and no more than fifteen (15) days in
one (1) calendar year.
6. Off Premises Advertising Or Directional Signs: Off premises advertising or directional signs shall
be permitted subject to the following standards and conditions:
a. Signs shall be sandwich board or ground signs that are portable. Subject to the special event
permit, signs may be erected only to coincide with the days of the event and shall be removed
within twenty four (24) hours after the conclusion of the event.
b. Signs shall be professionally designed and painted on all sides, including any support posts.
c. Signs placed on private property shall be erected with permission of the property owner or
lessee.
d. Signs may be placed in City rights-of-way excluding State and County rights-of-way; however,
signs shall be set back from the back of all curbs by no less than two feet (2') per one foot (1')
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 205/771
of sign height. Signs shall be limited to one (1) per street intersection and shall not interfere
with traffic visibility or pedestrian ways.
e. Signs shall not be located more than two (2) miles from the site of the event and no more than
twenty five (25) signs per event are permitted.
f. Signs shall include the special event information and shall include the name and phone
number for the business/organization sponsoring the event.
g. Sign area shall be limited to twelve (12) square feet.
h. Signs shall be anchored to the ground.
i. Signs shall not be illuminated.
j. Signs shall not be attached to any tree or permanent structure including, but not limited to, light
or power poles, utility infrastructure, or buildings.
(B) Community Event Signs: Community event signs shall be permitted subject to the following
standards and conditions:
1. Signs shall be sandwich board or freestanding signs and may be erected up to seventeen (17)
days prior to the event and shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after the conclusion of
the event.
2. Signs shall be professionally designed and painted on all sides, including any support posts.
3. Signs placed on private property shall be erected with permission of the property owner or
lessee.
4. Signs may be placed in City rights-of-way excluding State and County rights-of-way; however,
signs shall be set back from the back of all curbs by no less than two feet (2') per one foot (1') of
sign height.
5. Off premises signs shall be limited to one (1) per street intersection and shall not interfere with
traffic visibility or pedestrian ways. On premises signs shall be limited to not more than one (1)
sign per entrance or driveway to the site where the event is being held.
6. Signs shall include the community event information and shall include the name and phone
number for the organization sponsoring the event.
7. Off premises community event signs shall not exceed twelve feet (12') in area. On premises
community event signs shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet in area.
8. Signs shall be anchored to the ground.
9. Signs shall not be illuminated.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 206/771
10. Signs shall not be attached to any tree or permanent structure including, but not limited to, light
or power poles, utility infrastructure, or buildings.
(C) Legacy Event Temporary Signs And Banners: Legacy Event temporary signs and banners shall be
permitted subject to the following standards and conditions:
1. Event organizers shall apply for a sign permit application through the Community Development
Department for all on and off premises signs and banners proposed on private property. The
application shall include event organizer contact information. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
2. Event organizers shall provide a map showing the proposed location of all on premises and off
premises signs and banners within right-of-way, public property and private property to the City
forty five (45) days prior to the event. Signs on private property may be identified by address.
(Ord. 1432, 8-22-2017)
3. A maximum of fifty (50) signs or banners may be erected thirty (30) days prior to the Legacy
Event. Additional signs and banners may be erected up to seventeen (17) days prior to the
event.
4. Signs and banners shall be professionally designed and painted on all sides, including any
support posts.
5. Signs and banners shall be anchored to the ground.
6. Signs and banners shall not be illuminated.
7. Signs and banners shall not be attached to any tree, light or power poles, utility infrastructure, or
across lanes of traffic. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
8. Signs and banners shall be removed forty eight (48) hours after the conclusion of the event.
(Ord. 1432, 8-22-2017)
9. Off premises sandwich board or freestanding signs may be installed in accordance with the
following standards:
a. May be placed in right-of-way in accordance with the following standards:
(1) Signs placed in City right-of-way shall not exceed thirty inches (30") tall and four (4) square
feet in area.
(2) Signs shall be set back a minimum of two feet (2') from the back of curb or edge of the
pavement.
(3) A maximum of one sign per intersection except at intersections where at least one of the
streets is greater than two (2) lanes, exclusive of turn lanes, then two (2) signs per
intersection are allowed. The location of the sign(s) may be placed at the intersection corner
or median. No signs shall be allowed between intersections.
(4) Event organizers shall apply for a right-of-way permit for all signs proposed on City
property or City right-of-way in accordance with City Policy 5.204.
(5) Signs may be placed in County or State right-of-way with the permission of the State or
County.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 207/771
b. May be placed on private property in accordance with the following standards:
(1) Signs placed on private property shall be erected with permission of the property owner or
lessee.
(2) Signs shall not exceed forty eight (48) square feet in area (12 feet x 4 feet).
(3) Where the property line extends into roadway, signs shall be set back a minimum of two
feet (2') from the back of curb or edge of the pavement.
10. Off premises banners shall comply with subsection 10-30-3(O) of this Code and may be
installed in accordance with the following standards:
a. Banners within the right-of-way may be installed in accordance with the following standards:
(1) One banner per street intersection.
(2) Event organizers shall apply for a right-of-way permit for all banners proposed on City
property or City right-of-way in accordance with City Policy 5.204.
(3) Banners shall not exceed forty eight (48) square feet in area (12 feet x 4 feet).
(4) Banners shall be set back a minimum of two feet (2') from the back of curb or edge of the
pavement.
(5) Shall be limited to one per street intersection and shall not interfere with traffic visibility or
pedestrian ways.
(6) Banners may be placed in County or State right-of-way with the permission of the State or
County.
(7) Banners may be placed on private property in accordance with the following standards:
(a) Banners placed on private property shall be erected with permission of the property
owner or lessee.
(b) Banners shall not exceed forty eight (48) square feet in area (12 feet x 4 feet).
(c) Where the property line extends into roadway, banners shall be set back a minimum of
two feet (2') from the back of curb or edge of the pavement.
11. On premises Legacy Event signs:
a. May be freestanding signs or sandwich boards or banners.
b. Shall not exceed forty eight (48) square feet in area.
c. Shall be set back a minimum of two feet (2') from the back of curb or edge of the pavement.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 208/771
d. Shall be limited to not more than two (2) signs or banners per entrance or driveway to the site
where the event is being held.
e. Banners shall comply with subsection 10-30-3(O) of this Code.
f. No limit on the number of freestanding, sandwich, or banner signs on premises, other than the
entrance(s) or driveway(s) as noted in this section.
g. Event organizers shall apply for a right-of-way permit for all signs proposed on City property or
City right-of-way in accordance with City Policy 5.204.
(D) Prohibited Advertising Devices For Indoor And Outdoor Promotional Sales Events On Private
Property Special Events: The advertising devices or activities described below are prohibited for
special events:
1. Animated signs, beacons, light bulb strings, pennants, portable signs, ribbons, and streamers.
2. Displays or special features on any landscaped areas or on roofs.
3. Aerial rides, except for events designated by the City as community Legacy Events.
4. Large balloons or collections of small balloons exceeding two feet (2') in diameter, except for
balloon arches not exceeding twenty feet (20') in height.
5. Additional lighting that does not meet this Code.
6. Any advertising device in the public right-of-way.
7. Hot air inflatable devices.
(E) Violations:
1. It is a violation for any person, company or organization to provide, erect, fail to remove or
display any beacons, balloons or other advertising device which is not in conformity with the
provisions of this section.
2. It is a violation for any person, company or organization to display special event signs and
decorations not removed by the last day of the special event. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-5: PERMIT REQUIRED:
(A) Permit Required: No special event as defined by section 3-32-2 of this chapter shall be held
without first obtaining a permit from the City in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. A
permit under this chapter does not exempt compliance with all other applicable local, State, and
Federal laws.
(B) The following special events are exempt from a special event permit as required by this chapter:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 209/771
1. Weddings, wedding receptions, anniversaries, birthdays, family reunions, funeral processions,
and graduation parties at residences or event centers on private property.
2. The use of traditional public forums as alternative channels of communication by the public,
provided that such use is for the free exercise of constitutionally protected activities and does not
disrupt or interfere with traffic on public streets or the use of public places by other members of
the public. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-6: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Persons seeking a permit under this chapter shall file with the City a written application a minimum of
fifteen (15) business days prior to the event on a form to be furnished by the City. The application shall
provide:
(A) A signed letter of permission from the property owner if different than the applicant stating that the
applicant has permission to conduct the event.
(B) A statement describing the proposed activity, description of any commercial activity, dates and
times of operation, number of employees or volunteers involved, estimated number of attendees,
provisions for on-site parking, sanitation and security, and other pertinent information required to
fully evaluate the application.
(C) A site plan or current aerial photo of the property showing sufficient detail to evaluate the event
location and placement of any temporary structures, such as tents, stands, portable toilets, and
signs associated with event.
(D) The location of the requested special event signs allowed by section 3-32-4 of this chapter shall be
included in the permit application. Only after the City issues the permit may the special event signs
be installed.
(E) Applications or valid permits for all regulated activities associated with the event including, but not
limited to, loudspeaker or similar device, temporary lifting of no parking requirements, street
closures, electrical permits, fire permits, and/or temporary alcohol sales. If selling food, a copy of
the applicable Minnesota Department of Health or Agriculture license shall be submitted with the
application.
(F) A statement detailing the event's expected impact on traffic, parking, public safety, and any other
relevant public services. A detailed plan for how the applicant will manage and mitigate these
impacts shall also be included.
(G) Road closure requests (except for residential block parties). The application shall include a signed
detour plan. All detour routes are to the discretion of the City Engineer. The City Engineer may
require a different route than proposed by the applicant in which case the applicant must revise
their detour plan and resubmit it. If no reasonable detour routes exist according to the City
Engineer, the license request for occupying the right-of-way may be denied by the City.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 210/771
1. Advance notice of the detour signs shall be given to the City Engineer or designee. The detour
signs shall be installed at each direction by a qualified traffic control company seven (7) days
prior to the event. The detour signage shall be placed by a qualified traffic control company and
remain throughout the duration of the event.
2. Emergency contact information for the event coordinator(s) or person(s) in charge of the event.
(Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-7: PERMIT CONDITIONS:
The City may place conditions on the time, place, and other aspects of any sale or event allowed by
this section as deemed necessary to mitigate the activity's impact on traffic, parking, public safety, or
other Municipal services. These conditions may include, but are not limited to:
(A) Changing the date(s), time(s), route, or location of the proposed activity.
(B) Alterations to the traffic control or safety/emergency plan.
(C) Limiting the activity's maximum attendance.
(D) Restricting the sale or consumption of food or alcohol.
(E) Removal of signs, advertising or promotional materials.
(F) Requirements for the cleanup and restoration of any public property.
(G) Requirements for appropriate sanitation facilities, waste receptacles, and availability of potable
water.
(H) Requirements designed to ensure compliance with applicable local, State, and Federal laws.
(I) Additional inspection fees incurred as a result of building, fire or zoning enforcement.
(J) Additional fees incurred by the City of Burnsville.
(K) Any other conditions which the City deems necessary. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-8: FEE:
(A) Permit Fee: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the person applying for the permit shall
pay a fee to cover the administrative costs of processing the application. The fee shall be in an
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 211/771
amount determined by Council resolution or ordinance and is not refundable if the permit is denied
or applicant withdraws or otherwise ceases operation or use of the permit. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-9: PERMIT POSTED:
The City shall issue a special event permit upon the filing of a properly signed and completed
application and associated materials. The special event applicant shall have their City permit posted at
the special event. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
3-32-10: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
(A) Regulations: A person with a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be allowed to
conduct the proposed activity within the City; provided, that none of the following occurs:
1. Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit.
2. Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the activity.
3. Requirements of the permit are not met.
4. Any violation of this chapter.
5. Conviction of any felony, gross misdemeanor, or a misdemeanor or violation of any local
ordinance, which adversely reflects upon the person's ability to conduct the business or activity
for which the permit is being sought in a professional, honest and legal manner. Such violations
shall include, but are not limited to, burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business
practices, and any form of actual or threatened physical harm against another person.
6. Conducting the business or other activity in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to
constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general
welfare of the public, including revocation of any State license or authority to operate such
business.
7. Conducting the business in a disreputable manner. Evidence of a bad business reputation shall
include, but is not limited to, the existence of more than three (3) complaints against an applicant
with the Better Business Bureau, the Office of the Minnesota Attorney General or other State
Attorney General's Office, or other similar business or consumer rights office or agency, within
the preceding twelve (12) months, or three (3) complaints filed with the City against an applicant
within the preceding five (5) years.
(B) Denial/Revocation: A permit shall be denied or revoked if any of the conduct listed in subsection
(A) of this section shall occur.
(C) Notice: Prior to denial, revoking or suspending any permit issued under this chapter, the City shall
provide the permit holder with written notice of the alleged violations and inform the permittee of
his or her right to an appeal on the alleged violation. Notice shall be delivered in person or by mail
to the permanent residential address listed on the application, or if no residential address is listed,
to the business address provided on the application.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 212/771
(D) Appeal: Upon receiving the notice provided the licensee shall have the right to appeal the adverse
license action according to section 1-4-6 of this Code.
(E) Emergency: If, in the discretion of the City Manager or City Council, imminent harm to the health or
safety of the public may occur because of the actions of the permit holder under this chapter, the
City Manager or Council may immediately suspend the person's permit and provide notice of the
right to appeal as prescribed in subsection (C) of this section. (Ord. 1417, 5-16-2017)
Title 4
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
BUILDING CODE
4-1-1: BUILDING CODE ADOPTION:
The Minnesota state building code, established pursuant to Minnesota statutes chapter 326B,
including all of the amendments, rules and regulations established, adopted and published from time
to time by the Minnesota commissioner of labor and industry through the building codes and
standards unit, is hereby adopted as the building code for the city. The code is hereby incorporated in
this chapter as if fully set out herein.
(A) Optional Provisions: The following optional provisions of the state building code are also adopted
by the city: Minnesota rules chapter 1335, floodproofing regulations, parts 1335.0600 to 1335.1200
and grading, international building code appendix J. (Ord. 1300, 5-14-2013)
(B) Application, Administration And Enforcement: The application, administration, and enforcement of
the code shall be in accordance with Minnesota state building code.
The code enforcement agency of this municipality is called the protective inspections department.
The code shall be enforced by the Minnesota certified building official designated by this
municipality to administer the code. (Ord. 1353, 9-8-2015)
(C) Violations And Penalties: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity for which a
license or permit is required under the state building code or city ordinance without first obtaining
the license or permit and having it in effect at all times. A violation of the code is a misdemeanor.
(D) Permits And Fees: The issuance of permits and the collection of fees shall be as authorized in the
state building code and the city fee ordinance. In addition, a surcharge fee shall be collected on all
permits issued for work governed by this code in accordance with Minnesota statutes section
326B.148. (Ord. 1300, 5-14-2013)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 213/771
(E) Certification Of Taxes Paid: Prior to the city processing or approving any permit application under
the city's official controls, the applicant shall provide certification to the city that there are no
delinquent property taxes, special assessments, interest, or city utility fees due for the property to
which the application relates. Applications for permits shall not be processed until outstanding
amounts are paid in full. Property taxes which are being paid under the provisions of a stipulation,
order, or confession of judgment, or which are being appealed as provided by law, are not
considered delinquent for purposes of this section provided all required payments that are due
under the terms of the stipulation, order, confession of judgment, or appeal have been paid. (Ord.
1230, 2-22-2011)
4-1-2: COMPLETION TIME:
Any construction for which a building permit has been issued for exterior work shall be completed and
ready for occupancy according to the approved plans and specifications within one hundred eighty
(180) days following issuance of said permit, unless within that time an extension is granted by the
building official. (Ord. 1395, 8-16-2016)
4-1-3: FEES:
A fee schedule shall be as established by the city council, from time to time. (Ord. 262, 8-1-1983)
4-1-4: EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL:
Prior to the start of any excavation, the builder must comply with the requirements as defined in
section 10-8-8 of this code. (Ord. 1316, 4-8-2014)
4-1-5: SITE CONDITIONS:
During construction, the construction site must be kept free of garbage and debris at the end of each
workday. Materials and equipment used for construction may be left on site. The perimeter of the site
abutting streets or adjacent properties shall be maintained a minimum of ten feet (10') inland.
Dumpsters are required and shall be removed before a certificate of occupancy is issued or final
inspection approved. (Ord. 1300, 5-14-2013)
4-1-6: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1316, 4-8-2014)
4-1-7: LANDSCAPING:
(A) The owner shall be responsible for establishing and maintaining turf grass or sod on all maintained
portions of the property within ten (10) days of the date of occupancy, or by June 18, if occupancy
takes place between September 1 and May 31. (Ord. 1353, 9-8-2015)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 214/771
(B) Maintained portions of the property include all front, side and rear yards, excluding any portion of
the property covered by driveway, sidewalks or other landscaping that is in conformity with all other
provisions of this code. (Ord. 1162, 5-19-2009; amd. Ord. 1300, 5-14-2013)
(C) During any interim periods where turf grass is not yet established or sod has not been placed, the
owner shall be responsible for placing and maintaining an approved method of "erosion and
sediment control" as defined in section 10-8-8 of this code. (Ord. 1316, 4-8-2014)
