8-6-3: PARK HOURS:
(A) Parks To Be Closed: All parks except Nicollet Commons park will close at ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
each day and shall remain closed until five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on the following day. Nicollet
Commons park will close at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight each day and shall remain closed until
five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on the following day. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no one
shall be in any park when the park is closed, nor when the park has been closed at other times
pursuant to order of the city manager.
(B) Activities Regulated: The following activities require a permit from the city to take place in parks
while the park is open:
1. Public sales of food or merchandise.
2. Private use of any portion of the park.
3. Tents or temporary structures.
4. Signs or announcements.
5. Amplified sounds of any type.
(C) Activities Permitted After Closing: The following activities may continue in parks after the park's
normal closing hours:
1. Use of the indoor ice arena and adjacent public parking facilities during hours when the ice
arena is being utilized.
2. Use of lighted tennis courts during the hours posted at the individual courts for tennis purposes.
3. City sponsored and supervised activities which, because of the nature of the activity, cannot be
held during the time when the parks are open.
4. Activities conducted pursuant to a permit issued under subsection (D) of this section.
(D) Permits: An individual, group, association or organization wishing to sponsor an activity which will
use city parks whilethe park is open or between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and five
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 352/771
o'clock (5:00) A.M. shall apply to the city manager for a permit not less than ten (10) days before
the date of the activity. The application shall be on forms provided by the city manager. The city
manager may impose conditions upon the conduct of the proposed activity, including limiting the
time of the activity. The city manager may also require as a condition for issuance of the permit an
indemnity bond holding the city harmless from liability of any kind or character and reimbursing the
city for any property damage or cleanup cost.
(E) Closing Of Parks By City Manager: The city manager may close any park or any portion thereof at
any time for protection of park property or for the public health, safety or welfare. (Ord. 914, 4-5-
2004)
8-6-4: SPECIAL USE:
No person or group shall have special use of all or any portion of a park unless they have first
reserved the property with the park and recreation department and procured a permit from the city
manager. Unless a special use permit is procured and a reservation is made, use of park property will
be on a first come, first serve basis. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-5: MOTOR VEHICLES:
(A) Operation: No person shall drive, operate or park a motor vehicle within a park except on roads or
designated parking areas or such other areas as the city shall designate. No person shall operate
a motor vehicle within a park at a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. No person shall
park a motor vehicle in an area other than a designated parking area.
(B) Parking: No person shall park any motor vehicle in a park during hours when the park is closed.
Any unoccupied vehicle found in violation of this section may be removed and impounded by any
police officer or duly authorized person.
(C) Vehicle Maintenance: No person shall wash, grease, dismantle, repair or undertake other motor
vehicle maintenance in a park.
(D) Restitution: In addition to the other penalties provided in this chapter, any person violating the
provisions of this section and causing damage to any park property, shall make restitution to the
city for the full value of damage done to park property, including, but not limited to, the cost of
repairs, replacement and labor. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-6: FIRES:
No person shall ignite a fire in any park except in places provided or receptacles manufactured for
such purposes. The igniting of fires may be further limited by park rule. No person igniting or attending
a fire shall leave the area before the fire has been completely extinguished. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-7: LITTER:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 353/771
(A) No person shall litter any park or any lake, pond or watercourse within or draining into a park with
any form of trash or waste material. Such trash or waste material shall be deposited in the proper
receptacles when provided; where receptacles are not provided, all trash or waste material shall be
carried away from the area by the person responsible for its presence.
(B) No person shall leave or store personal property within any park without permission from the city.
(Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-8: PROTECTION OF PROPERTY, STRUCTURES AND NATURAL RESOURCES:
(A) Damaging Or Removing Property Prohibited: No person shall wilfully deface, vandalize or
otherwise cause destruction to park property.
(B) Flowers, Trees And Shrubs: No person shall wilfully and without authority cut, pluck or otherwise
injure any flowers, shrubs, trees or other plant material growing in or around any park. No person
shall introduce any form of vegetation within a park without permission from the city.
(C) Birds Or Animals: No person shall wilfully and without authority kill, trap, hunt, pursue or in any
manner disturb or interfere with any species of wildlife in any park. No person shall release any
insect, fish or animal in any park or public land without permission from the city.
(D) Restitution: In addition to the other penalties provided in this chapter, any person violating the
provisions of this section shall make restitution to the city for the full value of the damage caused,
including, but not limited to, the cost of repairs, replacement and labor. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-9: ALCOHOL:
Intoxicating liquors and 3.2 percent malt liquor may only be consumed and displayed in a park, subject
to the following provisions:
(A) Intoxicating Liquors: Except for 3.2 percent malt liquorand wine, no person shall consume or
display intoxicating liquors without first having procured a permit from the city. (Ord. 276, 6-17-
1985; amd. Ord. 634, 8-5-1996)
(B) Glass: No person shall bring glass beverage containers or glass drinking containers into a park.
(Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
(C) Roadways And Parking Lots: No person shall display or consume intoxicating liquors or 3.2
percent malt liquor on or within thirty feet (30') of any roadway or parking lot within a park.
(D) Prohibited Areas: No person shall possess, display or consume intoxicating liquors or 3.2 percent
malt liquor within areas in which the city has designated that such possession, display or
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 354/771
consumption is prohibited.
(E) Quantities: No person shall bring into a park intoxicating liquors or 3.2 percent malt liquor in kegs
or barrels, except as provided in this section. Groups, associations or organizations desiring to
bring intoxicating liquors or 3.2 percent malt liquor into parks in kegs or barrels may do so only
after obtaining a permit for such use from the city. The city shall grant the application if in its
judgment the use for which the permit is sought will not interfere with the health, safety, welfare
and the use of the park by the general public and if the applicant meets all other conditions as may
be contained in the permit issued by the city. Such use shall only be conducted in areas
designated in the permit. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985; amd. Ord. 634, 8-5-1996)
8-6-10: ANIMALS:
(A) Where animals are permitted, they shall be restricted at all times by a suitable leash not exceeding
six feet (6') in length and under command of the owner or custodian.
(B) No person shall permit a dog or other animal to disturb, harass or interfere with or endanger any
visitor or visitor's property. No person shall tether and leave unattended any dog or animal to a
tree, plant, building or park equipment.
(C) Any person having the custody or control of any dog or animal shall have the duty to immediately
remove any feces left by such animal in any park and to dispose of such feces in a sanitary
manner. It shall furthermore be the duty of each person having custody or control of any dog or
domestic animal in a park to have in such person's possession a device or equipment for the
picking up and removing of animal feces. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to a
guide dog accompanying a blind person or to a dog when used in police or rescue activities. (Ord.
276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-11: GOLF:
(A) Hitting Of Golf Balls Prohibited: No person shall hit, drive, stroke or otherwise propel a golf ball
upon, in, over, across or into a park except within areas that have been designated for such
activity.
(B) Hitting Of Practice Golf Balls: Unless specifically prohibited, practice golf balls may be hit in parks
provided:
1. The practice golf ball is a thin hollow sphere of plastic or other similar lightweight material; and
2. The practice golf ball is hit only off a pad of sufficient thickness to protect the natural turf from
divits. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-12: RESTROOMS:
Every person shall cooperate in maintaining restrooms, washrooms and other sanitation facilities in a
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 355/771
neat, orderly and sanitary condition. No person over the age of four (4) years shall use the restrooms
and washrooms designed and designated for members of the opposite sex. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-13: GROUP ACTIVITY:
Groups, associations or organizations of twenty five (25) or more individuals desiring to use park
facilities for parties, public meetings, assemblies, entertainment, parades, demonstrations or other
similar gatherings, may do so only after first obtaining a permit for such use from the city manager.
The city manager shall grant the application if in his judgment the use for which the permit is sought
will not interfere with the health, safety, welfare and the use of the park by the general public and if the
applicant meets all other conditions as may be contained in the permit. Such activities shall only be
conducted in areas designated in the permit. The city manager may require an indemnity bond, in
form and substance satisfactory to the city attorney, holding the city harmless from liability of any kind
or character and which bond shall protect the city in case of property damage. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-14: PUBLIC SALES:
No person shall within any park expose or offer for sale, rent or hire any article or thing or conduct any
commercial enterprise unless that person has obtained a permit from the city. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-15: POSTERS AND ADVERTISEMENTS:
(A) No person shall post, glue, tack or otherwise affix any sign, placard, advertisement or other
inscription whatsoever to public property within any park.
(B) No person shall distribute or disseminate leaflets, pamphlets or other written or printed material, or
use loudspeakers or other amplifying systems, in any park without a permit from the city. Permits
shall be freely granted, but they may contain reasonable time, place and manner restrictions. (Ord.
276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-16: DESIGNATED AREAS:
(A) No person shall play games which interfere with appropriate use of the amphitheater, arbor, rinks,
ski trails, walking and hiking trails, sledding or tobogganing areas, or use hockey sticks or pucks in
areas not designated for hockey play or loiter on the ice or in the park buildings.
(B) No person shall use park property or facilities in such a way that such use interferes with the
primary character of the property or facility, or interferes with the use of the property by a person or
group which has reserved park property for a specific use. (Ord. 914, 4-5-2004)
8-6-17: BODIES OF WATER:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 356/771
(A) Swimming, Bathing Or Wading: No person shall bathe, swim or wade in any lake, pond or
watercourse within a park except in designated swimming or wading areas. All persons shall
comply with the posted rules in designated swimming areas.
(B) Use Of Underwater Breathing Apparatus: No person shall use skin diving, aqua lungs or any other
underwater breathing apparatus or equipment in any park waters without first obtaining a permit
therefor from the city.
(C) Use Of Flotation Equipment: No person shall use air mattresses, inner tubes or other inflated
articles or other flotation equipment in any park property unless specifically allowed by park rule or
unless such flotation devices shall have a Minnesota state watercraft license, or are coast guard
approved life vests, or are used in conjunction with a sanctioned swimming or water safety class.
(D) Boat Launching And Parking Of Trailers: No person shall launch a boat from park lands except at
designated locations and times. No person shall violate the posted rules relating to public boat
launching and parking of trailers.
(E) Fishing: No person shall fish in any park area designated as a "no fishing" area. No person shall
violate the posted rules related to public fishing on park lands. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-18: MISSILES:
No person shall throw or cast any stone or other missile in disregard of the rights and safety of others
or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. (Ord. 276, 6-17-
1985)
8-6-19: AUTHORIZED PERSONS:
City agents, employees and police officers acting in their official capacity are exempted from the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 276, 6-17-1985)
8-6-20: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon
conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than seven hundred dollars ($700.00) or
imprisonment in jail for not more than ninety (90) days. Citations may be issued by a community
service officer, police officer, or other city employees designated by the city manager. (Ord. 564, 5-1-
1995)
8-6-21: PATHS:
(A) The city manager may designate exclusive paths for bikes and pedestrians within Terrace Oaks
park.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 357/771
(B) Bikes are prohibited on designated pedestrian paths and pedestrians on foot are prohibited on
designated bike paths. (Ord. 475, 2-1-1993)
8-6-22: PARK RULES:
Any person who violates park rules may be ordered to cease and desist by a police officer, community
service officer, or other city employees designated by the city manager. If the violation continues after
an order to cease and desist, a police officer, community service officer, or other city employees
designated by the city manager may order the violator to leave the park. Failure to leave the park
when ordered to do so is a misdemeanor. (Ord. 564, 5-1-1995)
Chapter 7
STREET LIGHTING
8-7-1: INSTALLATION:
Streetlights shall be installed at points designated by the city engineer in the development of new
subdivisions.
The city council may, pursuant to chapter 429 of Minnesota statutes, also determine the streets,
alleys, or other public or private areas on which the city shall install and operate lighting systems.
Before any such service is furnished pursuant to such resolutions, the council will meet to consider
such projects. (Ord. 831, 11-5-2001)
8-7-2: COSTS:
The costs of installation of streetlights in new subdivisions shall be the responsibility of the developer.
The developer shall also be responsible for the operation and maintenance cost of streetlights until the
streets and lighting system are accepted by the city.
The cost of installation of streetlights on existing streets, alleys, or public or private areas shall be
assigned at the direction of the city council as directed in the adopted street lighting policy. (Ord. 831,
11-5-2001)
8-7-3: STREET LIGHTING UTILITY:
Pursuant to Minnesota statutes, section 429.101, the city establishes a street lighting utility and
authorizes the imposition of charges for the operation of the street lighting system. (Ord. 831, 11-5-
2001)
8-7-4: FUND ESTABLISHED:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 358/771
There is hereby created a streetlight utility fund, into which all charges, when collected, and all monies
received from the sale of any facilities or equipment or any byproducts shall be placed. Such monies
shall be used to pay the costs of operating, maintaining, and replacement of the street lightingsystem.
(Ord. 831, 11-5-2001)
8-7-5: CALCULATION OF CHARGES:
The city council shall, by resolution, from time to time establish rates and charges for the use of the
street lighting system, and shall determine a schedule of rates to be charged to users. Rates for
various types of land uses and properties shall be established by resolution. (Ord. 831, 11-5-2001)
8-7-6: PAYMENT OF CHARGES AND COLLECTIONS:
All fees are charges against the respective owners, lessees, or occupants and are due on the due
date specified by the city for the respective account, and shall be delinquent thirty (30) days thereafter.
Unpaid charges shall be specially assessed against the benefited property pursuant to Minnesota
statutes, section 429.101. To each account, there shall be added an administrative charge for the
preparation of certification of delinquent accounts in the amount provided for by council resolution.
(Ord. 831, 11-5-2001)
Chapter 8
SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FOR CURRENT SERVICES
8-8-1: DEFINITION:
The term "current service" as used in this chapter means one or more of the following: snow, ice, or
rubbish removal from sidewalks; weed elimination from streets, boulevards, or private property;
removal or elimination of public health or safety hazards from private property, excluding any
hazardous building included in Minnesota statutes sections 463.152 and 463.26; installation or repair
of water service lines; street sprinkling, street flushing, light street oiling, or other dust treatment of
streets; repair of sidewalks and alleys; trimming and care of trees and removal of unsound and insect
infested trees from the public streets or private property; inspections relating to building, housing and
property maintenance code violations; the operation and maintenance of a fire protection or a
pedestrian skyway system, or other special charges that may be special assessments under
Minnesota statutes section 429.101, as amended. (Ord. 1395, 8-16-2016)
8-8-2: LEVY OF SPECIAL ASSESSMENT:
The city may collect the cost of current services performed by the city as a special assessment
against the property benefited. After notice and hearing as provided in Minnesota statutes section
429.061, the city council may spread the charges against property benefited as a special assessment
under Minnesota statutes section 429.101 and other pertinent statutes for certification to the county
auditor and collection along with current taxes the following year or in annual installments, not
exceeding ten (10) as the council may determine in each case. (Ord. 316, 4-4-1988)
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 359/771
Chapter 9
LAC LAVON MOTORIZED VEHICLE ORDINANCE
8-9-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall hereafter be known and cited as the "Lac Lavon Motorized Vehicle Ordinance".
8-9-2: PURPOSE:
It shall be the intent of the provisions of these regulations to achieve the following objectives:
(A) To preserve the natural beauty of Lac Lavon;
(B) To promote the peaceful enjoyment of Lac Lavon and protect the public health, safety and general
welfare of those who utilize its facilities;
(C) To provide for the compatibility of various uses of the lake and surrounding park area;
(D) To limit the congestion, pollution and noise caused by certain motorized activities by setting
standards for and limiting the use thereof.
8-9-3: PROHIBITION:
No motorized vehicle or motorboat shall be utilized on Lac Lavon except in compliance with this
Chapter.
8-9-4: EXEMPTION:
Motorized vehicles or motorboats used by authorized resource management or emergency and
enforcement personnel acting in the course of their employment shall be exempt from this Chapter.
8-9-5: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings given herein:
DAYTIME: That part of each calendar day between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) A.M. and ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M.
MOTORBOAT: Shall have the meaning given in Minnesota Statutes section 361.02, subdivision 8.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 360/771
MOTORIZED VEHICLE: (1) Any self-propelled vehicle or
(2) Any vehicle propelled or drawn by any self-propelled vehicle or floatation device. This term
includes snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles. All-terrain vehicles shall have the meaning given
in Minnesota Statutes section 84.92, Subdivision 8.
NIGHTTIME: That part of each calendar day between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight to five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice, steered by skis, skids or
runners.
8-9-6: USE STANDARDS:
(A) No person shall operate or permit the operation of any motorized vehicle or motorboat powered by
internal combustion gasoline or diesel engines on Lac Lavon.
(B) The operation of motorized vehicles or motorboats powered by electric motors shall be allowed on
Lac Lavon during the daytime provided that:
1. No person shall operate a motorized vehicle or motorboat in such a condition of disrepair as to
create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise.
2. No person shall create any loud and excessive noise in connection with the unloading or
unpacking of any motorized vehicle or motorboat.
8-9-7: PENALTIES:
Any person found in violation of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
Each day any violation or failure to perform such act shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 321, 7-5-88)
Chapter 10
CRYSTAL LAKE WATER SURFACE MANAGEMENT
ORDINANCE
8-10-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and cited as "Crystal Lake Water Surface Management Ordinance".
8-10-2: PURPOSE:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 361/771
The purpose of this Ordinance is to enhance and preserve the recreational use, safety, and enjoyment
of Crystal Lake.
8-10-3: PROHIBITION:
No watercraft shall be utilized on Crystal Lake except in compliance with this Chapter.
8-10-4: EXEMPTION:
Authorized resource management, emergency and enforcement personnel when acting in the
performance of their assigned duties shall be exempt from this Chapter.
8-10-5: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings given herein:
SLOW-NO WAKE: Operation of a watercraft at the slowest possible speed necessary to maintain
steerage and in no case greater than five (5) miles an hour.
WATERCRAFT: Any contrivance used or designed for navigation on water, other than seaplanes.
8-10-6: SLOW-NO WAKE ZONES:
(A) Maple Island Bay and Buck Hill Bay shall be slow-no wakezones.
(B) From shore to a distance of one hundred fifty feet (150') from shore shall be a slow-no wake zone.
There shall not be a slow-no wake zone around Pik Nik Island.
(C) All of Crystal Lake shall be a slow-no wake zone when the lake water elevation is nine hundred
thirty four feet (934') or greater, as measured at the outlet pipe at the west end of the lake.
(D) No water craft towing a person on water skis, aquaplane, or similar device shall be operated at
any time in any slow-no wake zone; provided, however, that any watercraft launching or landing a
person on water skis, aquaplane or similar device by the most direct route to open water or shore
shall be exempt from this Section 8-10-6(D).
8-10-7: USE STANDARDS; SPEED LIMITS:
(A) All watercraft traffic on the lake exceeding a slow-no wake speed shall travel in a counterclockwise
direction.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 362/771
(B) The maximum speed limit for watercraft from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to sunset shall be forty (40)
miles per hour, except as provided in Section 8-10-6(A), (B), and (C).
(C) The maximum speed limit for watercraft from sunset to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. shall be fifteen
(15) miles per hour.
8-10-8: PENALTIES:
Violation of any provision of this Chapter shall be a misdemeanor. (Ord. 332, 1-17-89)
Chapter 11
WATER SURFACE MANAGEMENT FOR KELLER LAKE
8-11-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall hereafter by known and cited as the WATER SURFACE MANAGEMENT
ORDINANCE FOR KELLER LAKE.
8-11-2: PURPOSE:
The intent of these regulations is to achieve the following objectives:
(A) To preserve the natural beauty of Keller Lake;
(B) To promote the peaceful enjoyment of Keller Lake and to protect the public health, safety and
general welfare of those who utilize its facilities;
(C) To provide for the compatibility of various uses of the lake and surrounding park area;
(D) To limit the congestion, pollution and noise caused by certain motorized activities by setting
standards for and limiting the use thereof.
8-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings given herein:
DAYTIME: The hours between five o'clock (5:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
MOTORIZED VEHICLE: Any motorized vehicle with an internal combustion engine, including but not
limited to cars, trucks, tractors, snowmobiles, motorcycles, motorbikes, all-terrain vehicles.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 363/771
NIGHTTIME: The hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to midnight and midnight to five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
REMOTE CONTROL INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINE BOAT: Any watercraft, including but not
limited to miniature and model boats controlled by the user by means of a control cable or radio
control unit and which is powered by an internal combustion engine. This does not include those
remote control boats powered by steam, electricity or wind.
WATERCRAFT: Any contrivance used or designed for navigation on water, except:
(A) A duck boat during the duck hunting season;
(B) A rice boat during the harvest season; or
(C) A seaplane.
8-11-4: PROHIBITION:
Except as specifically authorized by Sections 8-11-5 and 8-11-6:
(A) No person shall operate any motorized vehicle on Keller Lake.
(B) No person shall operate a watercraft with more than a five (5) horsepower motor on Keller Lake.
(C) No person shall operate a remote control internal combustion engine watercraft on Keller Lake.
(D) No person shall operate a watercraft during nighttime on Keller Lake.
8-11-5: EXEMPTION:
Motorized vehicles or motorboats used by rescue personnel or authorized resource management or
enforcement personnel acting in the course of their employment shall be exempt from this Chapter.
8-11-6: ALLOWED USE:
The operation of watercraft with a five (5) horsepower motor or less is permitted during the daytime.
8-11-7: PRIMARY ENFORCEMENT:
Primary enforcement of this Chapter shall rest with the Burnsville Police Department. Other licensed
peace officers, including the Dakota County Sheriff's Department and conservation officers of the
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 364/771
Department of Natural Resources are also authorized to enforce the sections involvingwatercraft, allterrain
vehicles, motor vehicles and snowmobiles.
8-11-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 439, 3-16-
92)
Chapter 12
WATER SURFACE MANAGEMENT FOR SMALL LAKES
AND PONDS
8-12-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall hereafter be known and cited as the WATER SURFACE MANAGEMENT
ORDINANCE FOR SMALL LAKES AND PONDS.
8-12-2: PURPOSE:
It shall be the intent of the provisions of these regulations to achieve the following objectives:
(A) To preserve the natural beauty of small lakes and ponds.
(B) To promote the peaceful enjoyment of small lakes and ponds and protect the public health, safety
and general welfare of those who utilize its facilities;
(C) To provide for the compatibility of various uses of the lake and surrounding park area;
(D) To limit the congestion, pollution and noise caused by certain motorized activities by setting
standards for and limiting the use thereof.
8-12-3: PROHIBITION:
(A) No person shall operate or permit the operation of any motorized vehicle, motorboat or remote
control boat powered by an internal combustion engine on small lakes and ponds except in
compliance with this Chapter.
(B) No electric trolling motor shall be allowed on Sunset Pond.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 365/771
(C) No boating whatsoever shall be allowed on the south half of Sunset Pond as marked by buoys or
signs. This area is a waterfowl nesting area.
(D) No person shall operate a watercraft during nighttime on any small lake or pond.
8-12-4: EXEMPTION:
Motorized vehicles or motorboats used by rescue personnel or authorized resource management or
enforcement personnel acting in the course of their employment shall be exempt from this Chapter.
The City may allow the use of remote control internal combustion engine boats at a specific location
after review of a reasonable request.
8-12-5: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings given herein:
DAYTIME: That part of each calendar day between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) A.M. and ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M.
MOTORBOAT: Shall have the meaning given in Minnesota Statutes, section 86B.005, subdivision 9.
MOTORIZED VEHICLE: (A) Any self-propelled vehicle or;
(B) Any vehicle propelled or drawn by any self-propelled vehicle or flotation device. This term
includes snowmobiles and all terrain vehicles. All terrain vehicles shall have the meaning given
in Minnesota Statutes, section 84.92, subdivision 8.
NIGHTTIME: That part of each calendar day between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to midnight
and midnight to five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
REMOTE CONTROL INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINE BOAT: Any watercraft, including but not
limited to miniature and model boats, controlled by the user by means of a control cable or radio
control unit and which is powered by an internal combustion engine. This does not include those
remote control boats powered by steam, electricity or wind.
SMALL LAKES AND PONDS: For the purpose of this Chapter, shall mean any lake or pond totally in
Burnsville which is sixty five (65) acres or less in size. Crystal Lake, Alimagnet Lake, and Lac Lavon
are all larger than sixty five (65) acres, and therefore the restrictions of this Chapter do not apply.
Keller Lake is partially in Apple Valley, and therefore the restrictions of this Chapter do not apply.
SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice, steered by skis, skids or
runners.
8-12-6: USE STANDARDS:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 366/771
Except as prohibited in Section 8-12-3, the operation of motorized vehicles or motorboats powered by
electric motors shall be allowed on any small lake or pond during the daytime provided that:
(A) No person shall operate a motorized vehicle or motorboat in such a condition of disrepair as to
create loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise.
(B) No person shall create any loud and excessive noise in connection with the unloading or
unpacking of any motorized vehicle or motorboat.
8-12-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 440, 3-16-
92)

TELECOMMUNICATIONS PERMIT REQUIREMENTS1

Chapter 14
RIGHT-OF-WAY
8-14-1: FINDINGS AND PURPOSE:
(A) Legislative Findings And Purpose: To provide for the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, and
to ensure the integrity of its streets and the appropriate use of the rights-of-way, the City strives to
keep its rights-of-way in a state of good repair and free from unnecessary encumbrances.
Accordingly, the City hereby enacts this chapter relating to right-of-way permits and administration.
This chapter imposes reasonable regulation on the placement and maintenance of facilities and
equipment currently within its rights-of-way or to be placed therein at some future time. It is
intended to complement the regulatory roles of State and Federal agencies. Under this chapter,
persons excavating and obstructing the rights-of-way will bear financial responsibility for their work.
Finally, this chapter provides for recovery of out of pocket and projected costs from persons using
the public rights-of-way.
This chapter shall be interpreted consistently with Minnesota Statutes sections 237.16, 237.162,
237.163, 237.79, 237.81, and 238.086 (the "Act") and the other laws governing applicable rights of
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 367/771
the City and users of the right-of-way. This chapter shall also be interpreted consistent with
Minnesota Rules 7819.0050 through 7819.9950 where possible. To the extent any provision of this
chapter cannot be interpreted consistently with the Minnesota Rules, the interpretation most
consistent with the Act and other applicable statutory and case law is intended. This chapter shall
not be interpreted to limit the regulatory and police powers of the City to adopt and enforce general
ordinances necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. This chapter goes
beyond regulating telecommunications companies as specifically authorized in the Act, and
extends to other persons seeking to use the rights-of-way within the City.
(B) Election To Manage The Public Rights-Of-Way: Pursuant to the authority granted to the City under
State and Federal statutory, administrative and common law, the City elects pursuant to Minnesota
Statutes section 237.163, subdivision 2(b), to manage rights-of-way within its jurisdiction. (Ord.
1282, 10-16-2012)
8-14-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions apply in this chapter:
APPLICANT: Any person requesting permission to excavate or obstruct a right-of-way.
BUS BENCH: Any bench privately owned and maintained on a public right-of-way for the convenience
and comfort of persons waiting for buses.
CITY: The City of Burnsville, Minnesota. For purposes of section 8-14-27 of this chapter, City means
its elected officials, officers, employees and agents.
COLLOCATE OR COLLOCATION: To install, mount, maintain, modify, operate, or replace a small
wireless facility on, under, within, or adjacent to an existing wireless support structure that is owned
privately or by a local government unit.
COMMISSION: The State Public Utilities Commission.
CONGESTED RIGHT-OF-WAY: A crowded condition in the subsurface of the public right-of-way that
occurs when the maximum lateral spacing between existing underground facilities does not allow for
construction of new underground facilities without using hand digging to expose the existing lateral
facilities in conformance with Minnesota Statutes section 216D.04, subdivision 3, over a continuous
length in excess of five hundred feet (500').
CONSTRUCTION PERFORMANCE BOND: A performance bond, or other form of security posted to
ensure the availability of sufficient funds to assure that right-of-way excavation and obstruction work is
completed in accordance with the terms of the right-of-way permit, or other applicable State law or
local regulation.
DEGRADATION: A decrease in the useful life of the right-of-way caused by excavation in or
disturbance of the right-of-way, resulting in the need to reconstruct such right-of-way earlier than
would be required if the excavation or disturbance did not occur.
DEGRADATION COST: Subject to Minnesota Rules 7819.1100 means the cost to achieve a level of
restoration as determined by the City at the time the permit is issued, not to exceed the maximum
restoration shown in Plates 1 to 13, set forth in Minnesota Rules parts 7819.9900 to 7819.9950.
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 368/771
DEGRADATION FEE: The estimated fee established at the time of permitting by the City to recover
costs associated with the decrease in the useful life of the right-of-way caused by the excavation, and
which equals the degradation cost.
DELAY PENALTY: The penalty imposed as a result of unreasonable delays in right-of-way excavation,
obstruction, patching, or restoration as established by permit. A delay penalty will not be imposed if
the delay in project completion is due to circumstances beyond the control of the applicant, including,
without limitation, inclement weather, acts of God, or civil strife.
DEPARTMENT: The Engineering Department of the City.
DEPARTMENT INSPECTOR: Any person authorized by the City to carry out inspections related to the
provisions of this chapter.
DIRECTOR: The City's Public Works Director, City Engineer, or designee.
EMERGENCY: A condition that: a) poses a danger to life or health, or of a significant loss of property;
or b) requires immediate repair or replacement of facilities in order to restore service to a customer.
EQUIPMENT: Any tangible asset used to install, repair, or maintain facilities in any right-of-way.
EXCAVATE: To dig into or in any way remove or physically disturb or penetrate any part of a right-ofway.
EXCAVATION PERMIT: The permit which, pursuant to this chapter, must be obtained before a person
may excavate in a right-of-way. An excavation permit allows the holder to excavate that part of the
right-of-way described in such permit.
EXCAVATION PERMIT FEE: Money paid to the City by an applicant to cover the costs as provided in
section 8-14-10 of this chapter.
FACILITY OR FACILITIES: Any tangible asset in the right-of-way required to provide utility service.
FIVE YEAR PROJECT PLAN: Shows projects adopted by the City for construction within the next five
(5) years.
HIGH DENSITY CORRIDOR: A designated portion of the public right-of-way within which
telecommunications right-of-way users having multiple and competing facilities may be required to
build and install facilities in a common conduit system or other common structure.
LOCAL REPRESENTATIVE: A local person or persons, or designee of such person or persons,
authorized by a registrant to accept service and to make decisions for that registrant regarding all
matters within the scope of this chapter.
MANAGEMENT COSTS: The actual costs the City incurs in managing its rights-of-way, including such
costs, if incurred, as those associated with registering applicants; issuing, processing, and verifying
right-of-way or small wireless facility permit applications; inspecting job sites and restoration projects;
maintaining, supporting, protecting, or moving user facilities during right-of-way work; determining the
adequacy of right-of-way restoration; restoring work inadequately performed after providing notice and
the opportunity to correct the work; and revoking right-of-way or small wireless facility permits.
Management costs do not include payment by a telecommunications right-of-way user for the use of
the right-of-way, unreasonable fees of a third-party contractor used by a local government unit as part
of managing its public rights-of-way, including but not limited to any third-party contractor fee tied to or
based upon customer counts, access lines, revenue generated by the telecommunications right-of6/
30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 369/771
way user, or revenue generated for a local government unit, or the fees and cost of litigation relating to
the interpretation of the Act or any ordinance enacted under the Act, or the City fees and costs related
to appeals taken pursuant to section 8-14-29 of this chapter.
MICRO WIRELESS FACILITY: A small wireless facility that is no larger than twenty four inches (24")
long, fifteen inches (15") wide, and twelve inches (12") high, and whose exterior antenna, if any, is no
longer than eleven inches (11").
OBSTRUCT: To place any tangible object in a right-of-way so as to hinder free and open passage over
that or any part of the right-of-way.
OBSTRUCTION PERMIT: The permit which, pursuant to this chapter, must be obtained before a
person may obstruct a right-of-way, allowing the holder to hinder free and open passage over the
specified portion of that right-of-way, for the duration specified therein.
OBSTRUCTION PERMIT FEE: Money paid to the City by a permittee to cover the costs as provided
in section 8-14-10 of this chapter.
PATCH OR PATCHING: A method of pavement replacement that is temporary in nature. A patch
consists of: a) the compaction of the subbase and aggregate base, and b) the replacement, in kind, of
the existing pavement for a minimum of two feet (2') beyond the edges of the excavation in all
directions. A patch is considered full restoration only when the pavement is included in the City's five
year project plan.
PAVEMENT: Any type of improved surface that is within the public right-of-way and that is paved or
otherwise constructed with bituminous, concrete, aggregate, or gravel.
PERMIT: Has the meaning given "right-of-way permit" in Minnesota Statutes section 237.162.
PERMITTEE: Any person to whom a permit to excavate or obstruct a right-of-way has been granted
by the City under this chapter.
PERSON: An individual or entity subject to the laws and rules of this State, however organized,
whether public or private, whether domestic or foreign, whether for profit or nonprofit, and whether
natural, corporate, or political.
PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY: The area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, cartway,
bicycle lane and public sidewalk in which the City has an interest, including other dedicated rights-ofway
for travel purposes and utility easements of the City. A right-of-way does not include the airwaves
above a right-of-way with regard to cellular or other nonwire telecommunications or broadcast service.
REGISTRANT: Any person, who: a) has or seeks to have its equipment or facilities located in any
right-of-way, or b) in any way occupies or uses, or seeks to occupy or use, the right-of-way or place its
facilities or equipment in the right-of-way.
RESTORE OR RESTORATION: The process by which an excavated right-of-way and surrounding
area, including pavement and foundation, is returned to the same condition and life expectancy that
existed before excavation.
RIGHT-OF-WAY PERMIT: Either the excavation permit or the obstruction permit, or both, depending
on the context, required by this chapter.
RIGHT-OF-WAY USER: (A) A telecommunications right-of-way user as defined by Minnesota Statutes
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 370/771
section 237.162, subdivision 4; or
(B) A person owning or controlling a facility in the right-of-way that is used or intended to be used
for providing utility service, and who has a right under law, franchise, or ordinance to use the
public right-of-way.
SERVICE OR UTILITY SERVICE: (A) Those services provided by a public utility as defined in
Minnesota Statutes 216B.02, subdivisions 4 and 6;
(B) Services of a telecommunications right-of-way user, including transporting of voice or data
information;
(C) Services of a cable communications system as defined in Minnesota Statutes chapter 238;
(D) Natural gas or electric energy or telecommunications services provided by the City;
(E) Services provided by a cooperative electric association organized under Minnesota Statutes
chapter 308A; and
(F) Water, sewer, steam, cooling or heating services.
SMALL WIRELESS FACILITY: (A) A wireless facility that meets both of the following qualifications:
1. Each antenna is located inside an enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet in volume or, in
the case of an antenna that has exposed elements, the antenna and all its exposed elements
could fit within an enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet; and
2. All other wireless equipment associated with the small wireless facility, excluding electric
meters, concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation boxes, battery backup
power systems, grounding equipment, power transfer switches, cutoff switches, cable,
conduit, vertical cable runs for the connection of power and other services, and any equipment
concealed from public view within or behind an existing structure or concealment, is in
aggregate no more than twenty eight (28) cubic feet in volume; or
(B) A micro wireless facility.
SUPPLEMENTARY APPLICATION: An application made to excavate or obstruct more of the right-ofway
than allowed in, or to extend, a permit that had already been issued.
TELECOMMUNICATION RIGHT-OF-WAY USER: A person owning or controlling a facility in the rightof-
way, or seeking to own or control a facility in the right-of-way that is used or is intended to be used
for providing wireless service, or transporting telecommunication or other voice or data information.
For purposes of this chapter, a cable communication system defined and regulated under Minnesota
Statutes chapter 238, and telecommunication activities related to providing natural gas or electric
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 371/771
energy services whether provided by a public utility as defined in Minnesota Statutes section 216B.02,
a municipality, a municipal gas or power agency organized under Minnesota Statutes chapter 453 and
453A, or a cooperative electric association organized under Minnesota Statutes chapter 308A, are not
telecommunications right-of-way users for purposes of this chapter except to the extent these entities
are offering wireless services.
TRANSIT SHELTER: Any transit shelter owned and maintained by a local public transit provider on a
public right-of-way for the convenience and comfort of persons waiting for buses.
UTILITY POLE: A pole that is used in whole or in part to facilitate telecommunications or electric
service.
WIRELESS FACILITY: (A) Equipment at a fixed location that enables the provision of wireless
services between user equipment and a wireless service network, including:
1. Equipment associated with wireless service;
2. A radio transceiver, antenna, coaxial or fiber-optic cable, regular and backup power supplies,
and comparable equipment, regardless of technological configuration; and
3. A small wireless facility.
(B) "Wireless facility" does not include:
1. Wireless support structures;
2. Wireline backhaul facilities; or
3. Coaxial or fiber-optic cables: a) between utility poles or wireless support structures, or b) that
are not otherwise immediately adjacent to or directly associated with a specific antenna.
WIRELESS SERVICE: Any service using licensed or unlicensed wireless spectrum, including the use
of Wi-Fi, whether at a fixed location or by means of a mobile device, that is provided using wireless
facilities. Wireless service does not include services regulated under title VI of the Communications
Act of 1934, as amended, including a cable service under United States Code, title 47, section 522,
clause (6).
WIRELESS SUPPORT STRUCTURE: A new or existing structure in a public right-of-way designed to
support or capable of supporting small wireless facilities, as reasonably determined by a local
government unit.
WIRELINE BACKHAUL FACILITY: A facility used to transport communications data by wire from a
wireless facility to a communications network. (Ord. 1434, 9-5-2017)
8-14-3: ADMINISTRATION:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 372/771
The Director is the principal City official responsible for the administration of the rights-of-way, right-ofway
permits, and the ordinances related thereto. The Director may delegate any or all of the duties
hereunder. (Ord. 1282, 10-16-2012)
8-14-4: RIGHT-OF-WAY OCCUPANCY AND REGISTRATION:
(A) Right-Of-Way Occupancy: No privately owned structure, sign or vending machine shall be located
within a public right-of-way with the exception of:
1. A mailbox for the use of receiving mail from the United States Postal Service or a newspaper
delivery.
2. Newspaper vending machines provided they comply with section 10-7-37 of this Code.
3. Bus benches, shelters, and transit facilities, provided they comply with this title. (Ord. 1308, 12-
3-2013)
(B) Registration: Each person who occupies, uses, or seeks to occupy or use the right-of-way or place
any equipment or facilities in or on the right-of-way, including persons with installation and
maintenance responsibilities by lease, sublease, collocation agreement or assignment, must
register with the City. Registration will consist of providing application information and paying a
registration fee. Registration fees shall be set by resolution of the City Council.
1. Registration Prior To Work: No person may construct, install, repair, remove, collocate, relocate,
or perform any other work on, or use any facilities or any part thereof in any right-of-way without
first being registered with the City. A person seeking to install a new wireless support structure
for the siting of a small wireless facility in a right-of-way in a district or areas zoned for or
allowing single family residential uses, or in an established historic district, is also required to
apply for and obtain a conditional use permit under title 10 of this Code.
2. Exceptions: Nothing herein shall be construed to repeal or amend the provisions of title 10,
chapter 30A of this Code, requiring or permitting persons to plant or maintain boulevard
plantings or gardens in the area of the right-of-way between their property and the street curb.
Persons installing or maintaining an irrigation system, landscaping or plantings on their property
shall not be required to obtain any permits or satisfy any other requirements under this chapter
for planting or maintaining such irrigation systems, boulevard plantings or gardens but are
required to obtain other appropriate permits from the City. For example, planting trees within City
rights-of-way or on City property requires a permit under section 8-3-3 of this title, all boulevard
landscaping must comply with all requirements of section 7-1-9 and title 10, chapter 30A of this
Code, all excavations must comply with the provisions of Minnesota Statutes chapter 216D,
Gopher One Call Law, that require location of underground utilities prior to excavations. (Ord.
1434, 9-5-2017)
8-14-5: REGISTRATION INFORMATION:
(A) Information Required: The information provided to the City at the time of registration shall include,
but not be limited to:
6/30/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=468 373/771

2. The name, address and e-mail address, if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of a

and permittees, including, but not limited to, protection against liability arising from completed
operations, damage of underground facilities and collapse of property, with coverage at least
to the limits of liability established by Minnesota Statutes section 466.04, or its successor;

force and applicable and for whom defense will be provided as to all such coverages;

material modification of a coverage term;
e. Indicating comprehensive liability coverage, automobile liability coverage, workers'
compensation and umbrella coverage established by the City in amounts sufficient to protect
the City and the public and to carry out the purposes and policies of this chapter.
4. The City may require a copy of the actual insurance policies.
5. If the person is a corporation, a copy of the certificate required to be filed under Minnesota law
with the Secretary of State.
6. A copy of the person's order granting a certificate of authority from the Minnesota Public Utilities
Commission or other applicable State or Federal agency, where the person is lawfully required
to have such certificate from said commission or other State or Federal agency.
(B) Notice Of Changes: The registrant shall keep all of the information listed above current at all times
by providing to the City information as to changes within thirty (30) days following the date on
which the registrant has knowledge of any change.

1. Permit Issuance: If the applicant has satisfied the requirements of this chapter, the City shall

2. Conditions: The Director may impose reasonable conditions upon the issuance of the permit and
